title: The not-so-great speciator: Systematics and species limits in the Asiatic white-eye complex (Zosterops spp.)
text:
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Introduction
text: This study is part of a decades-long international collaboration to learn about the systematics, evolution, and island biogeography of East Asian and Philippine birds. This chapter in that story involves the systematics of a particularly complex group within the white-eye genus Zosterops. The systematics of the white-eyes of East Asia and the Philippines, dubbed the Asiatic white-eyes, has proven to be confounding. Various studies have made strides in understanding this group but have suffered from insufficient sampling to tackle this particular problem (Lim et al. 2018; JONES and KENNEDY 2008; Gwee et al. 2020; Oliveros, Andersen, and Moyle 2021; Moyle et al. 2009). With the help of collaborators at the University of Kansas we produced a RADseq dataset and coupled that genome-wide genetic data with a smaller allele-based Sanger sequenced dataset and phenotypic data from linear morphometrics from museum study skins. Here we will describe in detail, perhaps excruciating, the methods and analyses in this work. The hope is that the work will be reproducible by our colleagues and accessible for students, especially for those learning to grapple with the complexities of large-scale single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) datasets.

title: Introduction
text:
Sampling
The strength of this study lies in its comprehensive sampling effort. 208 genetic samples and 354 museum skins were analyzed from several museums in the United States, China, Taiwan, and Japan. All of the sampling in this study is accessioned in natural history museums.



An author (HLM) collecting samples on Lanyu Island.


For the Asiatic white-eye complex we have sampled from many populations for the genetic analysis including all but three of the 15 subspecies within the combined Z. japonicus and Z. montanus group. This sampling was geographically widespread ranging from large temperate islands such as Hokkaido and Honshu, tiny, far-flung oceanic islands such as those in the Volcano group in the Western Pacific, and a variety of tropical islands in the Philippine and Indonesian archipelagos, as well as multiple taxa and populations for continental species ranging from Singapore to the Russian Far East.



An author (BDM) with Zosterops japonicus on the Japanese island of Tsushima.

title: Introduction
text:
Lab work and analysis
All the bench work for this project was conducted either at the University of Kansas for RADseq or Marshall University and Cincinnati Museum Center for the Sanger sequenced loci. Initial analyses were done at the University of Kansas by Devon DeRaad and published in the journal Biological Invasions (DeRaad et al. 2024). Where those initial analyses focused on using the RADseq data and ecological niche modeling to study the origin and spread of the introduced populations in Hawaii and Southern California, this study takes those data and adds Sanger sequences and morphology to focus on the systematics of the group in Asia. The initial basic filtering and preparation of the RADseq data for analysis is documented in (DeRaad et al. 2024). All the analyses here are directed toward solving the puzzle of the species limits within this group and determining their relationships. The lead on those integrative analyses were done by Herman Mays Jr.Â at Marshall University with considerable help from Laura Kubatko at Ohio State University.



A view of lab work in the lab of one of the authors (HLM) at Marshall University.

title: Introduction
text:
Museum morphometrics
Species are more than just the accumulation of neutral genetic differences. We added phenotypic data to these analyses to make for a more inclusive and integrative investigation of species limits and evolution in this group. Phenotypes in this study were focused on linear morphometrics derived from museum skins. Access to museum collections was generously provided by the American Museum of Natural History, Cincinnati Museum Center, The Field Museum, and the National Museum of Natural History at the Smithsonian. We have immense gratitude for these institutions and their staff for maintaining these collections and making them accessible.



Specimens of Zosterops nigrorum catarmanensis (top) and Z. montanus at the Field Museum, Chicago, IL.

title: Introduction
text:
Acknowledgements
Herman L. Mays Jr., PhD (HLM) conducted these analyses and created this document. This research was only possible through decades of collaboration with colleagues and institutions in Taiwan, China, and Japan, the support of museum collections in the USA, and training and collaboration with Laura Kubatko at The Ohio State University. Support for HLM was provided by the National Science Foundation through a Mid-career Award (NSF#2322123). Additional acknowledgments appear in the published account of this work. Questions about these analyses and research program are welcomed and should be directed to HLM at maysh@marshall.edu or maysher@gmail.com. Additional information about the broader research program may be found at https://www.monofilia.org.

title: StarBEAST2
text: What follows is our workflow for the StarBEAST2 (Ogilvie, Bouckaert, and Drummond 2017) analysis for Zosterops. In this analysis we will generate Zosterops species trees from our individual Sanger sequenced loci using Bayesian phylogenetic inference and the Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm.

title: StarBEAST2
text: What follows is our workflow for the StarBEAST2 (Ogilvie, Bouckaert, and Drummond 2017) analysis for Zosterops. In this analysis we will generate Zosterops species trees from our individual Sanger sequenced loci using Bayesian phylogenetic inference and the Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm.

title: StarBEAST2
text:
Getting started
We are using BEAST v2.7.4 for the analysis (R. Bouckaert et al. 2019, 2014; Alexei J. Drummond et al. 2012; Alexei J. Drummond and Rambaut 2007). Quarto version 1.6.39 for Mac OS was used to document the workflow.

title: StarBEAST2
text:
Data files
This analysis requires the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) alignments and the phased nuclear coding DNA (nuDNA) alignments from the Sanger sequenced loci. The protocol for phasing the nuDNA alignments may be found in the Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees section. In addition a taxon set file will be required to assign individual samples to their taxon and/or population of origin.
Subsequent analysis requires the following fasta files including the mtDNA alignments and the phased nuDNA alignments from the procedure described in the Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees section.

COI.fasta
ND2.fasta
B3GNT9_phased.fasta
BIRC2_phased.fasta
CCDC_phased.fasta
GPRC6_phased.fasta
LACTBL_phased.fasta
USP38_phased.fasta

Below are the taxon set files required for these analyses.

Zosterops taxon sets A.txt
Zosterops taxon sets B.txt

title: StarBEAST2
text:
Software and packages
BEAST2 software is available here. This analysis was conducted on a prior version of BEAST2 (v2.7.4 available here) but nearly identical results were achieved using the most recent version of BEAST2 (v2.7.7 as of the writing of this protocol). BEAUTi2 is the tool available with BEAST2 that allows for package management and a graphical user interface (GUI) to generate the xml files needed to run analyses. The programs LogCombiner and TreeAnnotator are also included with the BEAST2 install and will be needed to process the results of the MCMC runs. In addition, the program Tracer will be required to assess the results of an MCMC run and FigTree to edit and visualize species trees produced by BEAST2. Below is a summary of the needed software for this analysis and links to downloads.

BEAST2 v2.7.4 (R. Bouckaert et al. 2019) This install will include BEAST2, BEAUTi2, LogCombiner, and TreeAnnotator.
Tracer (Rambaut et al. 2018)
FigTree

In addition the following packages will need to be installed from the BEAUTi2 GUI using the package manager. To install packages in BEAUTi2 select File from the top bar and Manage Packages from the drop down menu. The package manager will display a table of installed packages and their latest versions. To install select the desired package and click on the Install/Upgrade button. After installing or upgrading packages you will have to close BEAUTi2 and restart before proceeding. Install the following packages.

bModelTest (R. R. Bouckaert and Drummond 2017)
StarBEAST2 (Ogilvie, Bouckaert, and Drummond 2017)

title: StarBEAST2
text:
Generating the xml file
After installing the needed packages restart BEAUTi2. From the File menu select Template and then StarBeast2. The StarBEAST2 template should display nine tabs titled as follows; Partitions, Taxon Sets, Tip Dates, Gene Ploidy, Population Model, Site Model, Clock Model, Priors, and MCMC.

Partitions
Sequence alignments will be added to the xml file in the Partitions tab. This can be done by either clicking the + button at the bottom of the tab and selecting Import Alignment from the subsequent menu options or by simply dragging the fasta file for each alignment into the Partitions tab. After specifying that an alignment is being imported select nucleotide when asked by BEAUTi2 to âChoose the datatypeâ. For each locus the correct number of taxa, sites, and data type should be listed. For each the file name will be used as the name BEAST2 uses for that particular locus. Also each locus should have a Site Model, Clock Model, and Tree unique to that alignment and with the same name. The Partition tab should look like this when completed.







Taxon sets
For the mtDNA alignments each individual sample has only a single sequence while there are two sequences for the diploid nuDNA alignments. The two phased sequences for each diploid individual sample should be labeled a and b (i.e.Â ZJja004a and ZJja004b are the two phased sequences for sample ZJja004). The a and b suffixes were automatically added to sample names for the phased sequences in PHASE 2.1.1 (see Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees). For consistency an a suffix was manually added to the sample name for each sequence in the mtDNA alignments to prevent a third sample name from appearing for each sample with both mtDNA and nuDNA sequences in the Taxon sets tab.
Some project numbers do not necessarily reflect the taxonomic origin of the individual samples. For example, samples ZJlo001 - ZJlo005 appear based on their project number designations to be Zosterops japonicus loochoensis but these project numbers were assigned in error before realizing they originated on the island of Chichijima outside the range of Z. japonicus loochoensis. For the Ogasawara Islands the subspecies designation for Z. japonicus is uncertain with some suspicion that these birds are subspecies hybrids between Z. japonicus stejnegeri in the Izu Islands and Z. japonicus alani in the Ogasawara/Volcano Islands. For our purposes we assigned birds in the Ogasawara and Volcano Islands the taxonomic designation Z. japonicus alani and birds in the Izu Islands Z. japonicus stejnegeri with the realization that gene flow may be occurring throughout these oceanic islands.
Click the Taxon sets tab. A list of sample names corresponding to the sequences in the alignments should appear in the Taxon column. For each sample a designation could be manually entered into the Species/Population column (time consuming) or automatically filled from a taxon sets file. To automatically add information on taxon assignment and/or population of origin click the Guess button at the bottom of the tab. Another window will open. Select the radio button corresponding to the read from file and the corresponding Browse button to select the appropriate taxon sets file. Click the Show options button and select txt to allow for the selection of txt files as taxon set entries. For the first set of BEAST2 runs samples were grouped by taxon (species and subspecies) and geography (island or island group) according to the Zosterops taxon sets A.txt file. This file is tab delimited and contains no headers and two columns with the identifying string for each individual sequence and the associated taxon and locality data as follows.

ZNlu001a    Zosterops nigrorum luzonicus LUZON
ZNme001a    Zosterops nigrorum meyleri CAMIGUINNORTE
ZNni001a    Zosterops nigrorum nigrorum PANAY
ZPxx001a    Zosterops simplex SINGAPORE
ZPxx002a    Zosterops simplex SINGAPORE
Different sets of StarBEAST2 runs will employ different xml files each with a different taxon set. Below is what the Taxon sets tab should look like with Zosterops taxon sets A.txt. The first run will be with this taxon set specifying both taxon and geographic localities.







Tip dates
The next tab in BEAUTi2 is the Tip Dates tab. The only selection in this tab is a check box associated with Use tip dates. Leave this box unchecked and proceed to the next tab.







Gene ploidy
The ploidy for each locus is set on the next tab titled, appropriately, Gene Ploidy. A list of loci corresponding to those alignments imported into the Partitions tab should appear in the Gene Ploidy tab. Enter the ploidy for each locus in the corresponding box. nuDNA loci are diploid and biparentally inherited so for those loci enter a ploidy of 2.0. The mtDNA loci are uniparentally inherited and haploid. For the mtDNA loci enter 0.5 in the ploidy box. When completed this tab should appear as follows.







Population Model
In the Population Model tab select Analytical Population Size integration from the drop-down menu.







Site Model
Substitution models for each unlinked locus are set in the Site Model tab. For each locus use bModelTest to estimate the best substitution model. If the bModelTest package (see Software and Packages section above) was installed then this option should be available in BEAUTi2 in the drop-down at the top of the Site Model tab as the BEAST Model Test option. For each locus select BEAST Model Test from the drop-down and for Mutation Rate click the estimate box. Mutation rates among loci are estimated relative to one another so leave the Mutation Rate at 1.0 for each locus. Repeat this process for each locus.







Clock Model
Next set the molecular clock model. Click on the Clock Model tab. For each locus added to the Partition tab there should be a corresponding entry listed in the Clock Model tab. For all loci select Strict Clock from the drop-down menu at the top of the tab. The substitution rate for mtDNA was based on a divergence rate of 2.1% per million years (Ma). This equates to a mean of 1.05% or 0.0105 substitutions/site/lineage/Ma. This range is consistent with mtDNA substitution rates reported in birds (FLEISCHER, MCINTOSH, and TARR 1998; Pereira and Baker 2006; WEIR and SCHLUTER 2008; Eo and DeWoody 2010). For both the mtDNA loci (COI and ND2) enter 0.0105 in the Clock.rate box and click the estimate box. For the nuDNA loci enter 0.00105 in the Clock.rate boxes and check the estimate box.







Priors
StarBEAST2 is a Bayesian method and as such it requires the user to set the priors for various parameters. For these analyses the default priors will be used for everything except for the clock rates. As we did for the Clock Model tab, clock rate priors will be based off of molecular clock rates estimated in the literature. Click on the Priors tab and scroll down to the strictClockRate values for each locus. Select the arrow symbol on the left to reveal the settings for the strictClockRate prior distribution for each locus. A LogNormal distribution from the drop down menu should be selected for all the strictClockRate priors. The box to the right should have the initial clock rate for each locus (same as defined in the Clock Rate tab) and show lower and upper bounds from 0.0 to infinity. Consistent with mtDNA substitution rates reported in birds (FLEISCHER, MCINTOSH, and TARR 1998; Pereira and Baker 2006; WEIR and SCHLUTER 2008; Eo and DeWoody 2010) the mean clock rate (M) for the mtDNA loci (COI and ND2) will be set at 0.0105 substitutions/site/lineage/Ma with a standard deviation (S) of 1.0. Make sure the Mean in Real Space box is checked to view the prior distribution. For the mtDNA loci M = 0.0105 and S = 1.0 and a log normal distribution results in a 5 - 95% quantile range of 0.00123 - 0.033 and a median clock rate of 0.00637. The same conditions should be set for each nuDNA locus prior except that the mean (M) should be set at 1/10th the clock rate of the mtDNA loci (M = 0.00105). For the nuDNA loci the 5 - 95% quantile range is 0.000123 - 0.0033 and the median clock rate is 0.000637.







MCMC
The final tab (MCMC) sets the parameters for the run. Enter 10 million (10000000) in the Chain Length box. Enter 20000 in the box titled Store Every to indicate that results should be stored every 20,000 iteration of the MCMC chain. The burnin period should be 1 million. Enter 1000000 into the corresponding Pre Burnin box. The number of initiation attempts should be 10 (enter 10 for the Num Initiation Attempts box). Leave the remaining parameters at their default values.







Save xml file
All the needed parameters for the xml file are now completed. Save the file by selecting File from the top bar in BEAUTi2 and Save as.
Replicate multiple independent runs in three groups. Group A uses the Zosterops taxon sets A.txt file in the xml setup with both taxon and island information to define the individual samples. Group B also uses both taxon and island information in the BEAUTi2 Taxon sets tab during the xml setup but employs the Zosterops taxon sets mtDNA.txt file to define the individual samples. Group A xml files include all loci in the Partitions tab. Group B xml files include only the two mtDNA loci (COI and ND2) in the Partitions tab. Group C runs include all loci in the Partitions tab but use the Zosterops taxon sets B.txt file to define the samples by taxon only, collapsing populations across multiple localities into the same taxonomic group.
Create a working directory for each run labeled appropriately (A1-20; B1-20; C1-20). Create one xml file for each of these groups and duplicate that file 20 times changing the file name to create a sequential series of xml files from 1 -20 (A1-A20 for Group A, B1-B20 for Group B, and C1-C20 for group C).
Names for xml files for the first runs in each group are as follows. âSTARBEAST274â denotes the version of StarBEAST2 used and BMT denotes that these runs use bModelTest for the site model selection.
Zosterops_STARBEAST274BMT_A1.xml
Zosterops_STARBEAST274BMT_B1.xml
Zosterops_STARBEAST274BMT_C1.xml

title: StarBEAST2
text:
MCMC BEAST2 Runs
There will be three sets of 20 MCMC runs for this analysis. For each run follow these instructions. Create a separate directory for each run labeled A1 - A20 for the Group A runs, B1 - B20 for the Group B runs, and C1 - C20 for the Group C runs. Each directory should contain the appropriate xml file created in BEAUTi2. Open BEAST2. The following dialog window should appear. Use the Choose fileâ¦ button to select the appropriate xml file for the run. A different value should appear in the Random number seed box with each separate run. If your machine will allow it, increase the number of threads and instances. Our runs were executed with 20 threads and 4 instances on either an Apple M1 iMac with 16GB RAM or an Apple M2 Max MacBook Pro with 96GB RAM. Click the Run button. Once BEAST2 is running the dialog window may be closed and the progress of the run monitored. Each run on either of these machines took approximately 30 - 40 minutes.

title: StarBEAST2
text:
Combining log and tree files
For each of the run groups (A, B, and C) combine the log and the trees files generated by BEAST and saved in the run directory. Open the LogCombiner application included with the BEAST2 download. For File type select Log Files from the drop-down. Drag and drop all the log files from StarBEAST2 runs within a group into the Select input files box. Click the Choose fileâ¦ button and at the prompt name the combined log file. Combined log files for the three groups of StarBEAST2 runs are as follows.
Zosterops_logs_A.log
Zosterops_logs_B.log
Zosterops_logs_C.log
Repeat the same process for the species tree files (trees) for the three run groups (A, B, and C). Combine the species trees from each run and not the individual locus trees. Open the LogCombiner application and select Tree Files from the File Type drop-down. Drag and drop all the trees files from StarBEAST2 runs within a group into the Select input files box. Click the Choose fileâ¦ button and at the prompt name the combined trees file. Combined trees files for the three groups of StarBEAST2 runs are as follows.
Zosterops_trees_A.trees
Zosterops_trees_B.trees
Zosterops_trees_C.trees

title: StarBEAST2
text:
Maximum clade credibility consensus tree
Open the TreeAnnotator application included with the BEAST2 download. Enter 10 for the Burn in percentage. Leave the Posterior probability limit at 0.0. Choose Maximum clade credibility tree from the drop-down menu for Target tree type and Common Ancestor heights for the Node heights. Select the combined species tree file from the previous step by clicking the Choose fileâ¦ button at the Input Tree File prompt. For the Output File selection click the Choose fileâ¦ button and name the file and choose the appropriate directory. Consensus species tree files are named as follows.
Zosterops_Speciestree_A.trees
Zosterops_Speciestree_B.trees
Zosterops_Speciestree_C.trees

title: StarBEAST2
text:
Results

A Runs
Consensus species tree from the A runs series of 20 replicate runs using all loci and the Zosterops taxon sets A.txt taxon set file. The tree is edited in FigTree with posterior probability displayed at the nodes.

Consensus species tree from the A runs series of 20 replicate runs using all loci and the Zosterops taxon sets A.txt taxon set file. The tree is edited in FigTree with 95% height displayed at the nodes and an axis in Ma.



B Runs
Consensus species tree from the B runs series of 20 replicate runs using only the mtDNA loci (COI and ND2) and the Zosterops taxon sets mtDNA.txt taxon set file. This taxon file has the same taxonomic and geographic designations as Zosterops taxon sets A.txt. The tree is edited in FigTree with posterior probability displayed at the nodes.

Consensus species tree from the B runs series of 20 replicate runs using only the mtDNA loci (COI and ND2) and the Zosterops taxon sets mtDNA.txt taxon set file. The tree is edited in FigTree with 95% height displayed at the nodes and an axis in Ma.



C Runs
Consensus species tree from the C runs series of 20 replicate runs using all loci and the Zosterops taxon sets B.txt taxon set file limited primarily to taxon designations. The tree is edited in FigTree with posterior probability displayed at the nodes and an axis in Ma.

title: Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees
text: What follows is our workflow for the general descriptive analysis of the Sanger sequencing data set for Zosterops. In this analysis we will describe the variation across individual Sanger sequenced loci and construct trees for each of these loci using distance-based and maximum likelihood methods.

title: Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees
text: What follows is our workflow for the general descriptive analysis of the Sanger sequencing data set for Zosterops. In this analysis we will describe the variation across individual Sanger sequenced loci and construct trees for each of these loci using distance-based and maximum likelihood methods.

title: Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees
text:
Getting started
We are using R version 4.4.2, RStudio version 2024.09.1 for the analysis. Quarto version 1.6.39 for Mac OS was used to document the workflow. Set the working directory in RStudio to one where the necessary phased Sanger sequencing alignments and other data are accessible.

title: Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees
text:
Data files
This dataset includes Sanger sequenced polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplicon alignments for two mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and six protein coding nuclear loci (nuDNA). Prior to this analysis Sanger sequencing ab1 files were uploaded to Geneiousâ 8.1.9 for editing, alignment, and quality control. Multiple sequencing runs for each amplicon were assembled and assembled loci were aligned across individual samples using Geneious Alignment. Alignments for each locus were trimmed and edited in Geneious and the identity of each locus confirmed with a megablast search. The reading frame was set by eye by avoiding frames with stop codons and a blastp search was done on the translation consensus for each alignment to confirm the locus identity. Alignments were exported as fasta files.
Alignments of diploid cdDNA loci were phased using PHASE 2.1.1 (Stephens, Smith, and Donnelly 2001). First, convert the alignment fasta files from Geneious to the inp format for PHASE 2.1.1 using the online SeqPHASE tool (Flot 2009). At the âGenotypes to be phasedâ prompt click the âBrowseâ button and select the appropriate fasta alignment. Click the âRun SeqPHASEâ button. Once step 1 of the SeqPHASE process is completed retain the seqphase.const file in addition to the seqphase.inp file and rename each file appropriately to match the locus name (e.g.Â B3GNT9_seqphase.inp and B3GNT9_seqphase.const for locus B3GNT9).
Move the inp file from SeqPHASE to the directory with PHASE 2.1.1 and cd to that directory in the terminal. The inp file is used to run the following PHASE 2.1.1 command in the terminal. For each locus <numberseed> should be replaced with an arbitrary number selected by the user and LOCUSNAME replaced with the designated name for that particular locus. Because each locus is relatively short chose the S option at the modeling flag (-M) as it assumes no within-locus recombination. Additional parameters are explained in the documentation for PHASE 2.1.1 available here.
./PHASE -MS -d1 -S<numberseed> -p0.85 -q0.85 -x5 -X10 LOCUSNAME_seqphase.inp LOCUSNAME_seqphase.out 5000 2 500 
Further analysis will require fasta alignments for each locus where each diploid individual is associated with two sequences corresponding to each of the two phased alleles determined in PHASE 2.1.1. Return to the online SeqPHASE tool and click the link to âstep 2â. Select the appropriate out file generated by the PHASE 2.1.1 run along with the matching const file generated from step 1 in the SeqPHASE tool. The âSort sequenceâ box should be checked but the âReduce sequencesâ box should not be checked. Click the âRun SeqPHASEâ button and SeqPHASE will return a fasta file with the complete sequence alignment and two phased haplotypes designated by the project number for that individual sample followed by a and b respectively. Click the âClick here to download the generated Fasta fileâ link at the bottom of the page and rename the file to match the locus name. Including the const file and unchecking the âReduced sequencesâ box will ensure the resulting fasta file includes the full length of the alignment, not just the variable sites.
The phasing procedure was repeated for the following nuDNA fasta alignments.

B3GNT9.fasta
BIRC2.fasta
CCDC.fasta
GPRC6.fasta
LACTBL.fasta
USP38.fasta

Subsequent analysis requires the following phased nuDNA alignments from the procedure described above.

COI.fasta
ND2.fasta
B3GNT9_phased.fasta
BIRC2_phased.fasta
CCDC_phased.fasta
GPRC6_phased.fasta
LACTBL_phased.fasta
USP38_phased.fasta

title: Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees
section: Description of summary statistics and tree building procedure for a single locus
text:
Description of summary statistics and tree building procedure for a single locus

Packages
Begin the analysis by restarting the R session (Session/Restart R in RStudio), loading the initial package libraries, and starting a log of the analysis. Other package libraries will be loaded as needed in later blocks. The following R packages should be installed using the Tools/Install Packages feature in RStudio.

logr (Bosak 2024) Optional if you wish to create a log file for the analysis.
ape (Paradis and Schliep 2019)
pegas (Paradis 2010)
phangorn (Schliep 2011)
gt (Iannone et al. 2024)
webshot2 (Chang 2025)
dplyr (Wickham et al. 2023)


library(logr)

Loading required package: common

log_open(file_name = "ZosteropsSangerSeqs.log")

library(ape)
library(pegas)

    mst

library(phangorn)


Attaching package: 'phangorn'

    dist.hamming




Cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI)


Load and visualize the alignment
First is a step-by-step protocol for the first locus (cytochrome c oxidase subunit I, COI). The same procedure will also be implemented for the other loci.
Load and check the fasta file and generate a standard color-coded visualization of the alignment.

#COI
#Load FASTA alignment and check
ZosteropsCOI <- read.dna("Data/Alignments/COI.fasta", format = "fasta")
ZosteropsCOI

132 DNA sequences in binary format stored in a matrix.

All sequences of same length: 646 

Labels:
ZAsu001a
ZAsu002a
ZEba001a
ZERxx001a
ZERxx002a
ZERxx003a
...

0.269 0.322 0.165 0.244 
(Total: 85.27 kb)

checkAlignment(ZosteropsCOI, check.gaps = FALSE, plot = TRUE, what = 1)


Number of sequences: 132 
Number of sites: 646 

Number of segregating sites (including gaps): 119
Number of sites with at least one substitution: 119
Number of sites with 1, 2, 3 or 4 observed bases:
  1   2   3   4 
527 108   9   2 











Pairwise divergence
Determine the pairwise divergences among the sequences and display the 40 least divergent pairwise comparisons and the 40 greatest pairwise comparisons. Also focus on a particular pair of samples between Z. japonicus and Z. montanus (i.e.Â ZJal003a and ZMOvu001a) to get an idea of the mtDNA divergence within this focal group.

# Calculate pairwise divergences
pw_div_COI <- dist.dna(ZosteropsCOI, model = "raw")
# Convert the distance matrix to a data frame
pw_div_df_COI <- as.data.frame(as.matrix(pw_div_COI))
# Add row names as a column
pw_div_df_COI$Sequence <- rownames(pw_div_df_COI)
# Create a long format data frame
pw_div_long_format_COI <- data.frame(Sequence = rep(pw_div_df_COI$Sequence, each = nrow(pw_div_df_COI)),
                               Comparison = rep(pw_div_df_COI$Sequence, times = nrow(pw_div_df_COI)),
                               Divergence = as.vector(as.matrix(pw_div_COI)))
# Remove self-comparisons
pw_div_long_format_COI <- pw_div_long_format_COI[pw_div_long_format_COI$Sequence != pw_div_long_format_COI$Comparison, ]
# Find the least 40 divergences
pw_div_least_COI <- head(pw_div_long_format_COI[order(pw_div_long_format_COI$Divergence), ], 40)
# Find the greatest 40 divergences
pw_div_greatest_COI <- head(pw_div_long_format_COI[order(-pw_div_long_format_COI$Divergence), ], 40)
# Combine least and greatest divergences
pw_div_combined_results_COI <- rbind(pw_div_least_COI, pw_div_greatest_COI)
# View the results
print(pw_div_combined_results_COI)

Number of sequences
Calculate the number of sequences in the alignment. Diploid phased nuDNA loci will have two sequences per individual sample and haploid mtDNA loci will have a single sequence per locus.

# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding the total 
# length by the sequence length (calculation 1) and by extracting 
# the length value from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesCOI1 <- lengthCOItotal/seqlengthCOI
SummaryCOIlength <- unlist(strsplit(summaryCOI[1,1], 
                                    split = ":", fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesCOI2 <- as.numeric(SummaryCOIlength)
all.equal(NumberSequencesCOI1, NumberSequencesCOI2)

[1] TRUE

NumberSequencesCOI1

[1] 132

NumberSequencesCOI2

[1] 132




ð estimates
Estimate ð per locus, ð per site, and ð variance based on the the number of segregating sites (theta.s) and also estimate ð per locus based on the number of alleles (theta.k).

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaCOIperLocusW <- theta.s(sCOI, NumberSequencesCOI1)
ThetaCOIperSiteW <- ThetaCOIperLocusW/seqlengthCOI
ThetaCOIperLocusVarW <- theta.s(sCOI, NumberSequencesCOI1, 
                                variance = TRUE)
ThetaCOIperLocusVarW <- ThetaCOIperLocusVarW[2]
ThetaCOIk <- theta.k(n = 132, k = 52)
ThetaCOIperLocusW

[1] 21.80995

ThetaCOIperSiteW

[1] 0.03376153

ThetaCOIperLocusVarW

[1] 30.15866

ThetaCOIk

[1] 31.16538




Tajimaâs D and R2 tests
Test for potential deviations from neutrality using Tajimaâs D (Tajima 1989) and population growth from the Ramos-Onsins and Rozaâs test (Ramos-Onsins and Rozas 2002).

# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and 
# Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaCOI <- tajima.test(ZosteropsCOI)
R2COI <- R2.test(ZosteropsCOI,B = 10000, 
                 theta = ThetaCOIperLocusW, plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

Trees

Distance-based trees
Generate trees using the unweighted pair group method with arithmetic mean (UPGMA) and neighbor joining (NJ) distance-based methods.

#UPGMA and NJ trees

UPGMAtreeCOI <- upgma(dmCOI)
NJtreeCOI <- NJ(dmCOI)
plot(UPGMAtreeCOI, main = "UPGMA COI", cex = 3)







plot(NJtreeCOI, "unrooted", main = "NJ COI", cex = 3)

title: Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees
section: Summary statistics and trees for the remaining loci
text:
Summary statistics and trees for the remaining loci
Below are the code blocks for the remaining loci grouped into loading and summarizing alignments, summary population statistics, and distance-based and ML trees.

NADH dehydrogenase 2 (ND2)

Load and visualize alignment

#ND2
#Load FASTA alignment and check
ZosteropsND2 <- read.dna("Data/Alignments/ND2.fasta", format = "fasta")
ZosteropsND2

143 DNA sequences in binary format stored in a matrix.

All sequences of same length: 978 

Labels:
ZAsu002a
ZEba001a
ZEba002a
ZEba003a
ZEbo001a
ZERxx001a
...

Base composition:
    a     c     g     t 
0.318 0.344 0.098 0.239 
(Total: 139.85 kb)

checkAlignment(ZosteropsND2, check.gaps = FALSE, plot = TRUE, what = 1)


Number of sequences: 143 
Number of sites: 978 

Number of segregating sites (including gaps): 235
Number of sites with at least one substitution: 235
Number of sites with 1, 2, 3 or 4 observed bases:
  1   2   3   4 
743 216  17   2 









Determine the pairwise divergences among the sequences and display the 40 least divergent pairwise comparisons and the 40 greatest pairwise comparisons.

# Calculate pairwise divergences
pw_div_ND2 <- dist.dna(ZosteropsND2, model = "raw")
# Convert the distance matrix to a data frame
pw_div_df_ND2 <- as.data.frame(as.matrix(pw_div_ND2))
# Add row names as a column
pw_div_df_ND2$Sequence <- rownames(pw_div_df_ND2)
# Create a long format data frame
pw_div_long_format_ND2 <- data.frame(Sequence = rep(pw_div_df_ND2$Sequence, each = nrow(pw_div_df_ND2)),
                                     Comparison = rep(pw_div_df_ND2$Sequence, times = nrow(pw_div_df_ND2)),
                                     Divergence = as.vector(as.matrix(pw_div_ND2)))
# Remove self-comparisons
pw_div_long_format_ND2 <- pw_div_long_format_ND2[pw_div_long_format_ND2$Sequence != pw_div_long_format_ND2$Comparison, ]
# Find the least 40 divergences
pw_div_least_ND2 <- head(pw_div_long_format_ND2[order(pw_div_long_format_ND2$Divergence), ], 40)
# Find the greatest 40 divergences
pw_div_greatest_ND2 <- head(pw_div_long_format_ND2[order(-pw_div_long_format_ND2$Divergence), ], 40)
# Combine least and greatest divergences
pw_div_combined_results_ND2 <- rbind(pw_div_least_ND2, pw_div_greatest_ND2)
# View the results
print(pw_div_combined_results_ND2)

summaryND2 <- summary(ZosteropsND2)



Summary statistics

# Nucleotide diversity
ndND2 <- nuc.div(ZosteropsND2)
# Number of haplotypes from phased DNA sequences (unique sequences) 
# and hapotype diversity
hapND2 <- haplotype(ZosteropsND2)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(ZosteropsND2): some sequences of different lengths
were assigned to the same haplotype

NumberHapsND2 <- nrow(hapND2)
hapdivND2 <- hap.div(ZosteropsND2)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences of different lengths were
assigned to the same haplotype

# An index of segregating sites and number of segregating sites 
seg.sitesND2 <- seg.sites(ZosteropsND2)
sND2 <- length(seg.sitesND2)
# Total length of all sequences (number of sequences x sequence length) 
# and sequence length
lengthND2total <- length(ZosteropsND2)
seqlengthND2 <- ncol(hapND2)
# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding the total length 
# by the sequence length (calculation 1) and by extracting 
# the length value from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesND21 <- lengthND2total/seqlengthND2
SummaryND2length <- unlist(strsplit(summaryND2[1,1], split = ":", 
                                    fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesND22 <- as.numeric(SummaryND2length)
all.equal(NumberSequencesND21, NumberSequencesND22)

[1] TRUE

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaND2perLocusW <- theta.s(sND2, NumberSequencesND21)
ThetaND2perSiteW <- ThetaND2perLocusW/seqlengthND2
ThetaND2perLocusVarW <- theta.s(sND2, NumberSequencesND21, variance = TRUE)
ThetaND2perLocusVarW <- ThetaND2perLocusVarW[2]
# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaND2 <- tajima.test(ZosteropsND2)
R2ND2 <- R2.test(ZosteropsND2,B = 10000, theta = ThetaND2perLocusW, 
                 plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

# An index of segregating sites and number of segregating sites 
seg.sitesB3GNT9 <- seg.sites(ZosteropsB3GNT9)
sB3GNT9 <- length(seg.sitesB3GNT9)
# Total length of all sequences (number of sequences x sequence length) 
# and sequence length
lengthB3GNT9total <- length(ZosteropsB3GNT9)
seqlengthB3GNT9 <- ncol(hapB3GNT9)
# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding the total length 
# by the sequence length (calculation 1) and by extracting the length value 
# from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesB3GNT91 <- lengthB3GNT9total/seqlengthB3GNT9
SummaryB3GNT9length <- unlist(strsplit(summaryB3GNT9[1,1], 
                                       split = ":", fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesB3GNT92 <- as.numeric(SummaryB3GNT9length)
all.equal(NumberSequencesB3GNT91, NumberSequencesB3GNT92)

[1] TRUE

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaB3GNT9perLocusW <- theta.s(sB3GNT9, NumberSequencesB3GNT91)
ThetaB3GNT9perSiteW <- ThetaB3GNT9perLocusW/seqlengthB3GNT9
ThetaB3GNT9perLocusVarW <- theta.s(sB3GNT9, NumberSequencesB3GNT91, 
                                   variance = TRUE)
ThetaB3GNT9perLocusVarW <- ThetaB3GNT9perLocusVarW[2]
# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaB3GNT9 <- tajima.test(ZosteropsB3GNT9)
R2B3GNT9 <- R2.test(ZosteropsB3GNT9,B = 10000, 
                    theta = ThetaB3GNT9perLocusW, plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

# An index of segregating sites and number of segregating sites 
seg.sitesBIRC2 <- seg.sites(ZosteropsBIRC2)
sBIRC2 <- length(seg.sitesBIRC2)
# Total length of all sequences (number of sequences x sequence length) 
# and sequence length
lengthBIRC2total <- length(ZosteropsBIRC2)
seqlengthBIRC2 <- ncol(hapBIRC2)
# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding the total length 
# by the sequence length (calculation 1) and by extracting 
# the length value from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesBIRC21 <- lengthBIRC2total/seqlengthBIRC2
SummaryBIRC2length <- unlist(strsplit(summaryBIRC2[1,1], split = ":", 
                                      fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesBIRC22 <- as.numeric(SummaryBIRC2length)
all.equal(NumberSequencesBIRC21, NumberSequencesBIRC22)

[1] TRUE

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaBIRC2perLocusW <- theta.s(sBIRC2, NumberSequencesBIRC21)
ThetaBIRC2perSiteW <- ThetaBIRC2perLocusW/seqlengthBIRC2
ThetaBIRC2perLocusVarW <- theta.s(sBIRC2, NumberSequencesBIRC21, 
                                  variance = TRUE)
ThetaBIRC2perLocusVarW <- ThetaBIRC2perLocusVarW[2]
# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaBIRC2 <- tajima.test(ZosteropsBIRC2)
R2BIRC2 <- R2.test(ZosteropsBIRC2,B = 10000, theta = ThetaBIRC2perLocusW, 
                   plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences of different lengths were

# An index of segregating sites and number of segregating sites 
seg.sitesCCDC <- seg.sites(ZosteropsCCDC)
sCCDC <- length(seg.sitesCCDC)
# Total length of all sequences (number of sequences x sequence length) 
# and sequence length
lengthCCDCtotal <- length(ZosteropsCCDC)
seqlengthCCDC <- ncol(hapCCDC)
# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding 
# the total length by the sequence length (calculation 1) 
# and by extracting the length value from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesCCDC1 <- lengthCCDCtotal/seqlengthCCDC
SummaryCCDClength <- unlist(strsplit(summaryCCDC[1,1], split = ":", 
                                     fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesCCDC2 <- as.numeric(SummaryCCDClength)
all.equal(NumberSequencesCCDC1, NumberSequencesCCDC2)

[1] TRUE

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaCCDCperLocusW <- theta.s(sCCDC, NumberSequencesCCDC1)
ThetaCCDCperSiteW <- ThetaCCDCperLocusW/seqlengthCCDC
ThetaCCDCperLocusVarW <- theta.s(sCCDC, NumberSequencesCCDC1, variance = TRUE)
ThetaCCDCperLocusVarW <- ThetaCCDCperLocusVarW[2]
# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaCCDC <- tajima.test(ZosteropsCCDC)
R2CCDC <- R2.test(ZosteropsCCDC,B = 10000, theta = ThetaCCDCperLocusW, 
                  plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

Summary statistics

# Nucleotide diversity
ndGPRC6 <- nuc.div(ZosteropsGPRC6)
# Number of haplotypes from phased DNA sequences (unique sequences) 
# and hapotype diversity
hapGPRC6 <- haplotype(ZosteropsGPRC6)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(ZosteropsGPRC6): some sequences of different
lengths were assigned to the same haplotype


Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(ZosteropsGPRC6): some sequences were not assigned
to the same haplotype because of ambiguities

NumberHapsGPRC6 <- nrow(hapGPRC6)
hapdivGPRC6 <- hap.div(ZosteropsGPRC6)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences of different lengths were
assigned to the same haplotype


Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences were not assigned to the same
haplotype because of ambiguities

# An index of segregating sites and number of segregating sites 
seg.sitesGPRC6 <- seg.sites(ZosteropsGPRC6)
sGPRC6 <- length(seg.sitesGPRC6)
# Total length of all sequences (number of sequences x sequence length) 
# and sequence length
lengthGPRC6total <- length(ZosteropsGPRC6)
seqlengthGPRC6 <- ncol(hapGPRC6)
# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding the total length 
# by the sequence length (calculation 1) and by extracting 
# the length value from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesGPRC61 <- lengthGPRC6total/seqlengthGPRC6
SummaryGPRC6length <- unlist(strsplit(summaryGPRC6[1,1], 
                                      split = ":", fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesGPRC62 <- as.numeric(SummaryGPRC6length)
all.equal(NumberSequencesGPRC61, NumberSequencesGPRC62)

[1] TRUE

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaGPRC6perLocusW <- theta.s(sGPRC6, NumberSequencesGPRC61)
ThetaGPRC6perSiteW <- ThetaGPRC6perLocusW/seqlengthGPRC6
ThetaGPRC6perLocusVarW <- theta.s(sGPRC6, NumberSequencesGPRC61, 
                                  variance = TRUE)
ThetaGPRC6perLocusVarW <- ThetaGPRC6perLocusVarW[2]
# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaGPRC6 <- tajima.test(ZosteropsGPRC6)
R2GPRC6 <- R2.test(ZosteropsGPRC6,B = 10000, 
                   theta = ThetaGPRC6perLocusW, plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

                  main="Maximum likelihood midpoint rooted standard bootstrap", 
                  cex = 3)







outgroupGPRC6 <- c("ZAsu001b","ZAsu002b")

summaryLACTBL <- summary(ZosteropsLACTBL)



Summary statistics

# Nucleotide diversity
ndLACTBL <- nuc.div(ZosteropsLACTBL)
# Number of haplotypes from phased DNA sequences (unique sequences) 
# and hapotype diversity
hapLACTBL <- haplotype(ZosteropsLACTBL)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(ZosteropsLACTBL): some sequences of different
lengths were assigned to the same haplotype


Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(ZosteropsLACTBL): some sequences were not assigned
to the same haplotype because of ambiguities

NumberHapsLACTBL <- nrow(hapLACTBL)
hapdivLACTBL <- hap.div(ZosteropsLACTBL)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences of different lengths were
assigned to the same haplotype


Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences were not assigned to the same
haplotype because of ambiguities

# An index of segregating sites and number of segregating sites 
seg.sitesLACTBL <- seg.sites(ZosteropsLACTBL)
sLACTBL <- length(seg.sitesLACTBL)
# Total length of all sequences (number of sequences x sequence length) 
# and sequence length
lengthLACTBLtotal <- length(ZosteropsLACTBL)
seqlengthLACTBL <- ncol(hapLACTBL)
# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding the total length 
# by the sequence length (calculation 1) and by extracting the length value 
# from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesLACTBL1 <- lengthLACTBLtotal/seqlengthLACTBL
SummaryLACTBLlength <- unlist(strsplit(summaryLACTBL[1,1], 
                                       split = ":", fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesLACTBL2 <- as.numeric(SummaryLACTBLlength)
all.equal(NumberSequencesLACTBL1, NumberSequencesLACTBL2)

[1] TRUE

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaLACTBLperLocusW <- theta.s(sLACTBL, NumberSequencesLACTBL1)
ThetaLACTBLperSiteW <- ThetaLACTBLperLocusW/seqlengthLACTBL
ThetaLACTBLperLocusVarW <- theta.s(sLACTBL, NumberSequencesLACTBL1, 
                                   variance = TRUE)
ThetaLACTBLperLocusVarW <- ThetaLACTBLperLocusVarW[2]
# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaLACTBL <- tajima.test(ZosteropsLACTBL)
R2LACTBL <- R2.test(ZosteropsLACTBL,B = 10000, 
                    theta = ThetaLACTBLperLocusW, plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

summaryUSP38 <- summary(ZosteropsUSP38)



Summary statistics

# Nucleotide diversity
ndUSP38 <- nuc.div(ZosteropsUSP38)
# Number of haplotypes from phased DNA sequences (unique sequences) 
# and hapotype diversity
hapUSP38 <- haplotype(ZosteropsUSP38)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(ZosteropsUSP38): some sequences of different
lengths were assigned to the same haplotype


Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(ZosteropsUSP38): some sequences were not assigned
to the same haplotype because of ambiguities

NumberHapsUSP38 <- nrow(hapUSP38)
hapdivUSP38 <- hap.div(ZosteropsUSP38)

Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences of different lengths were
assigned to the same haplotype


Warning in haplotype.DNAbin(x): some sequences were not assigned to the same
haplotype because of ambiguities

# An index of segregating sites and number of segregating sites 
seg.sitesUSP38 <- seg.sites(ZosteropsUSP38)
sUSP38 <- length(seg.sitesUSP38)
# Total length of all sequences (number of sequences x sequence length) 
# and sequence length
lengthUSP38total <- length(ZosteropsUSP38)
seqlengthUSP38 <- ncol(hapUSP38)
# Number of sequences calulated two ways, by divdiding the total length 
# by the sequence length (calculation 1) and by extracting 
# the length value from the summary (caclulation 2)
# Confirm both calculations for number of sequences are the same
NumberSequencesUSP381 <- lengthUSP38total/seqlengthUSP38
SummaryUSP38length <- unlist(strsplit(summaryUSP38[1,1], split = ":", 
                                      fixed = TRUE))[2]
NumberSequencesUSP382 <- as.numeric(SummaryUSP38length)
all.equal(NumberSequencesUSP381, NumberSequencesUSP382)

[1] TRUE

# Calculate theta per sequence, theta per site, theta variance 
# from the Watterson estimator based on number of segregating sites.
ThetaUSP38perLocusW <- theta.s(sUSP38, NumberSequencesUSP381)
ThetaUSP38perSiteW <- ThetaUSP38perLocusW/seqlengthUSP38
ThetaUSP38perLocusVarW <- theta.s(sUSP38, NumberSequencesUSP381, 
                                  variance = TRUE)
ThetaUSP38perLocusVarW <- ThetaUSP38perLocusVarW[2]
# Tests for neutrality including Tajima's D and Ramos-Onsins and Roza's test
tajimaUSP38 <- tajima.test(ZosteropsUSP38)
R2USP38 <- R2.test(ZosteropsUSP38,B = 10000, 
                   theta = ThetaUSP38perLocusW, plot = TRUE, quiet = FALSE)

title: Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees
text:
Summary table for all loci

Load libraries
Create a table that summarizes the population genetic data across all loci. First, load the gt and dplyr package libraries.

library(gt)


Attaching package: 'gt'


The following object is masked from 'package:ape':

    where

library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'

The following object is masked from 'package:ape':

    where


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(webshot2)



Create summary table
Create the summary table from the population genetic parameters estimated for each locus.

#Create table from estimates across all loci.
LocusNames <- c("COI","ND2", "B3GNT9", "BIRC2", 
                "CCDC", "GPRC6", "LACTBL", "USP38")
LocusType <- c("mt", "mt", "nu", "nu", "nu", "nu", "nu", "nu")
NumberIndividuals <- c(NumberSequencesCOI1, NumberSequencesND21, 
                       NumberSequencesB3GNT91/2, NumberSequencesBIRC21/2, 
                       NumberSequencesCCDC1/2, NumberSequencesGPRC61/2, 
                       NumberSequencesLACTBL1/2, NumberSequencesUSP381/2)
NumberSequences <- c(NumberSequencesCOI1, NumberSequencesND21, 
                     NumberSequencesB3GNT91, NumberSequencesBIRC21, 
                     NumberSequencesCCDC1, NumberSequencesGPRC61, 
                     NumberSequencesLACTBL1, NumberSequencesUSP381)
SequenceLength <- c(seqlengthCOI, seqlengthND2, seqlengthB3GNT9, 
                    seqlengthBIRC2, seqlengthCCDC, seqlengthGPRC6, 
                    seqlengthLACTBL, seqlengthUSP38)
SegSites <- c(sCOI, sND2, sB3GNT9, sBIRC2, sCCDC, sGPRC6, sLACTBL, sUSP38)
NucleotideDiversity <- c(ndCOI, ndND2, ndB3GNT9, ndBIRC2, 
                         ndCCDC, ndGPRC6, ndLACTBL, ndUSP38)
NucleotideDiversity <- round(NucleotideDiversity, digits = 3)
NumberHaplotypes <- c(NumberHapsCOI, NumberHapsND2, NumberHapsB3GNT9, 
                      NumberHapsBIRC2, NumberHapsCCDC, NumberHapsGPRC6, 
                      NumberHapsLACTBL, NumberHapsUSP38)
HaplotypeDiversity <- c(hapdivCOI, hapdivND2, hapdivB3GNT9, hapdivBIRC2, 
                        hapdivCCDC, hapdivGPRC6, hapdivLACTBL, hapdivUSP38)
HaplotypeDiversity <- round(HaplotypeDiversity, digits = 2)
ThetaWperLocus <- c(ThetaCOIperLocusW, ThetaND2perLocusW, 
                    ThetaB3GNT9perLocusW, ThetaBIRC2perLocusW, 
                    ThetaCCDCperLocusW, ThetaGPRC6perLocusW, 
                    ThetaLACTBLperLocusW, ThetaUSP38perLocusW)
ThetaWperLocus <- round(ThetaWperLocus, digits = 2)
ThetaWvariance <- c(ThetaND2perLocusVarW, ThetaND2perLocusVarW, 
                    ThetaB3GNT9perLocusVarW, ThetaBIRC2perLocusVarW, 
                    ThetaCCDCperLocusVarW, ThetaGPRC6perLocusVarW, 
                    ThetaLACTBLperLocusVarW, ThetaUSP38perLocusVarW)
ThetaWvariance <- round(ThetaWvariance, digits = 2)
ThetaWperSite <- c(ThetaCOIperSiteW, ThetaND2perSiteW, ThetaB3GNT9perSiteW, 
                   ThetaBIRC2perSiteW, ThetaCCDCperSiteW, ThetaGPRC6perSiteW, 
                   ThetaLACTBLperSiteW, ThetaUSP38perSiteW)
ThetaWperSite <- round(ThetaWperSite, digits = 3)
Tajima <- c(tajimaCOI$D,tajimaND2$D, tajimaB3GNT9$D, tajimaBIRC2$D, 
            tajimaCCDC$D, tajimaGPRC6$D, tajimaLACTBL$D, tajimaUSP38$D)
Tajima <- round(Tajima, digits = 2)
TajimaPValue <- c(tajimaCOI$Pval.normal,tajimaND2$Pval.normal, 
                  tajimaB3GNT9$Pval.normal, tajimaBIRC2$Pval.normal, 
                  tajimaCCDC$Pval.normal, tajimaGPRC6$Pval.normal, 
                  tajimaLACTBL$Pval.normal, tajimaUSP38$Pval.normal)
TajimaPValue <- round(TajimaPValue, digits = 3)
R2Test <- c(R2COI$R2, R2ND2$R2, R2B3GNT9$R2, R2BIRC2$R2, R2CCDC$R2, 
            R2GPRC6$R2, R2LACTBL$R2, R2USP38$R2)
R2Test <- round(R2Test, digits = 2)
R2TestPValue <- c(R2COI$P.val, R2ND2$P.val, R2B3GNT9$P.val, 
                  R2BIRC2$P.val, R2CCDC$P.val, R2GPRC6$P.val, 
                  R2LACTBL$P.val, R2USP38$P.val)
R2TestPValue <- round(R2TestPValue, digits = 3)
AllLociSummary <- data.frame(LocusNames, LocusType, NumberIndividuals, 
                             NumberSequences, SequenceLength, SegSites, 
                             NucleotideDiversity, NumberHaplotypes, 
                             HaplotypeDiversity, ThetaWperLocus, 
                             ThetaWvariance, ThetaWperSite, Tajima, 
                             TajimaPValue, R2Test, R2TestPValue)
colnames(AllLociSummary) <- c("Locus", "Locus type", "Individuals", 
                              "Number of sequences", "Length", 
                              "Segregating sites", "\u03C0", 
                              "Number of haplotypes", "Haplotype diversity", 
                              "\u03B8 per locus", "\u03B8 per locus variance", 
                              "\u03B8 per site", "Tajima's D", 
                              "Tajima's D p-value", "R2 test", 
                              "R2 test p-value")

title: Sampling Maps
text: What follows is our workflow for mapping the sampling localities for all the individual samples included in the Zosterops single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) dataset generated from a double digest restriction-site associated DNA (ddRAD) library (see DeRaad et al.2024 for details on the ddRAD library (DeRaad et al. 2024).

title: Sampling Maps
text: What follows is our workflow for mapping the sampling localities for all the individual samples included in the Zosterops single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) dataset generated from a double digest restriction-site associated DNA (ddRAD) library (see DeRaad et al.2024 for details on the ddRAD library (DeRaad et al. 2024).

title: Sampling Maps
text:
Getting started
We are using R version 4.4.2, RStudio version 2024.09.1 for the analysis. Quarto version 1.6.39 for Mac OS was used to document the workflow. Set the working directory in RStudio to one where the txt file denoting the identity and sampling location of the samples are accessible.

title: Sampling Maps
text:
Data files
This analysis requires the following data files.

ZosteropsPOPS4_LatLong.txt A text file of individual samples included in the SNP dataset matched with taxon, locale, and latitude and longitude.
ZosteropsPOPS_SANGER_LatLong.txt A text file of individual samples included in the Sanger sequencing dataset but that do not appear in the SNP dataset matched with taxon, locale, and latitude and longitude.


Individual samples and collecting localities: SNPs
A tab delimited text file with the individual sample IDs, taxon designations, the name of the sampling locales (designated by island or province), and latitude and longitude was created to generate maps. To reduce the amount of clutter on the maps subspecies were clustered together in shared geographic groups. Zosterops japonicus subspecies were designated as either Z. japonicus alani for the most remote subspecies in the Volcano Islands or grouped within a single Z. japonicus designation for all the remaining subspecies. Subspecies for Z. montanus were clustered into three groups including a Palawan group (montanus PALAWAN) consisting of Z. montanus parkesi, a northern Philippine group (montanus NORTH) for those subspecies on Mindoro and Luzon (Z. montanus halconensis amd Z. montanus whiteheadi), and a southern Philippine group (montanus SOUTH) including the remaining Z. montanus subspecies included in the study (Z. montanus diuatae, Z. montanus montanus, Z. montanus pectoralis, Z. montanus vulcani, and an unnamed but suggested subspecies on Panay). Subspecies within the Z. everetti and Z. nigrorum species were lumped together under a single species designation for each in the sampling maps but distinguished in later analyses. Samples from introduced populations in Hawaii and California are included in this list, but they are excluded from the final figure. The individual samples and their accompanying data from the file ZosteropsPOPS4_LatLong.txt are listed below. All of the samples listed in this file appear in the SNP analyses.

title: Sampling Maps
text:
Packages
Set the working directory to one where the data files ZosteropsPOPS4_LatLong.txt and Zosterops_SANGER_LatLong.txt are accessible. Creating the sampling maps requires the following R packages.

logr (Bosak 2024) Optional if you wish to create a log file for the analysis.
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)
maps (Becker, Minka, and Deckmyn. 2024)
sf (Pebesma and Bivand 2023)

Install the packages using the Tools/Install Packages selection from the RStudio menu and load the package libraries.

library(logr)

Loading required package: common

log_open(file_name = "ZosteropsMaps.log")

[1] "./log/ZosteropsMaps.log"

#load in each library used for mapping
library(ggplot2) #v3.4.1
library(maps) #v3.4.1
library(sf) #v1.0-12

Linking to GEOS 3.11.0, GDAL 3.5.3, PROJ 9.1.0; sf_use_s2() is TRUE

title: Sampling Maps
section: Read and edit data: SNP sampling
text:
Read and edit data: SNP sampling
Read the data into a data frame using read.csv and indicate that the fields are tab delimited (sep = "\t") and contain a header row (header = TRUE). First complete this process for the sampling data for the SNP dataset.

# Read tab delimited (sep = "\t") file with latitude and longitude
ZLocations <- read.csv(
  "Data/Location files/ZosteropsPOPS4_LatLong.txt", 
                       sep = "\t", header = TRUE)

Remove the samples from the introduced populations. Those samples are from Los Angeles (Z. simplex) and Hawaii (Z. japonicus) and are included in analyses but will not appear on the sampling maps.

# Remove Los Angeles and Hawaii samples
ZLocations_NATIVE <- ZLocations[-c(105,106,107,120,121,122,123,124),]

title: Sampling Maps
section: Count individual samples per taxon: SNP sampling
text:
Count individual samples per taxon: SNP sampling
To illustrate the relative number of individual samples from any particular site we will count the number of samples associated with a unique latitude and longitude. First split the data frame by the TAXON column.

# Split by TAXON
Zlocations_NATIVE_TAXON <- split(ZLocations_NATIVE, 
                                 ZLocations_NATIVE$TAXON)

Using a loop count samples grouped by LAT and LONG columns and save this as a new data frame called sampling.df.

# init sampling.df which will be a df of samples grouped by unique lat/long
sampling.df<-data.frame(NULL)
# use a for loop to split the dataframe by species and summarize the number 
# of individuals sampled at each locality for each species
for (i in names(Zlocations_NATIVE_TAXON)){
  samps <- Zlocations_NATIVE_TAXON[[i]] %>% 
    dplyr::group_by(LAT, LONG) %>% 
    dplyr::summarize(count=dplyr::n())
  df <- cbind(rep(i, times=nrow(samps)), samps)
  sampling.df <- as.data.frame(rbind(sampling.df, df))
}

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'LAT'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.

title: Sampling Maps
section: Read and edit data: Sanger sampling
text:
Read and edit data: Sanger sampling
Repeat the process above for the file containing the additional samples included in the Sanger sequencing dataset. There are no samples from introduced populations in the Sanger sequencing data so there is no need to follow up with the editing step.

# Pull location data for samples in the SANGER sequencing dataset 
# but not in the NSP dataset
# Read tab delimited (sep = "\t") file with latitude and longitude
ZLocationsSANGER <- read.csv(
  "Data/Location files/ZosteropsPOPS_SANGER_LatLong.txt", 
                             sep = "\t", header = TRUE)

title: Sampling Maps
section: Count individual samples per taxon: Sanger sampling
text:
Count individual samples per taxon: Sanger sampling
Split the data frame for the Sanger sequencing sampling by the TAXON column.

# Split by TAXON
ZlocationsSANGER_TAXON <- split(ZLocationsSANGER, 
                                ZLocationsSANGER$TAXON)

Using a loop count samples grouped by LAT and LONG columns and save this as a new data frame called samplingSANGER.df.

# init samplingSANGER.df which will be a df of samples 
# grouped by unique lat/long
samplingSANGER.df<-data.frame(NULL)
#use a for loop to split the dataframe by species and 
#summarize the number of individuals sampled at each 
#locality for each species
for (i in names(ZlocationsSANGER_TAXON)){
  samps <- ZlocationsSANGER_TAXON[[i]] %>% 
    dplyr::group_by(LAT, LONG) %>% 
    dplyr::summarize(count=dplyr::n())
  df <- cbind(rep(i, times=nrow(samps)), samps)
  samplingSANGER.df <- as.data.frame(rbind(samplingSANGER.df, df))
}

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'LAT'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.

title: Sampling Maps
text:
Create a sampling map

Mapping all samples
Download a world base map.

#make base world map
pac<-map_data("world")

First create a sampling map for all the Zosterops samples in the study (excluding those from introduced populations). Include two lines with the geo_point command. One line will define those points from the SNP sampling data frame (sampling.df) and identify those points as filled circles (pch=21). The next line will define the points using the geo_point command for the additional Sanger sequencing samples (samplingSANGER.df) and identify those points as triangles (pch=24). Because many of the sampling locations are the same for different taxa define position = position_jitter(h=0.5, w=0.5) to offset the points on the map so as they do not perfectly overlap. Also set alpha=0.5 to make the points transparent. This will also help in showing those places where sampled taxa overlap in location.

# plot all native samples
ggplot()+
  geom_polygon(data = pac, aes(x=long, y = lat, group = group), 
               fill="lightgrey", col="black", cex=.1)+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(90, 145), ylim = c(-10, 48)) + 
  geom_point(data = sampling.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                     fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.5, w = 0.5), pch=21, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=TRUE) +
  geom_point(data = samplingSANGER.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                           fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.5, w = 0.5), pch=24, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=TRUE) +
  theme_classic()+
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", 
                             "#290AD8", "#FED439", "#B66DFF", 
                             "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                             "#7BA9CB", "#008600"))+
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(3,6))+
  guides(fill = guide_legend(override.aes = list(size = 8), order=1, 
                             label.theme = element_text(face = "italic"), 
                             position = "left"),
         linewidth = guide_legend(order = 2))+
  theme(legend.position = "left")

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
â¹ Please use `linewidth` instead.









Save the sampling map as a png file.

# Save the sampling plot
ggsave("ZosteropsSamplingMapALL.png", device = "png", 
       width = 9, height = 6.5, units = "in", dpi = 500)



Mapping Ryukyu Island samples
Because many of the samples were collected on small islands and may appear close together at a large scale, create more geographically focused maps for particular regions with heavy sampling. This may be accomplished by editing the coord_sf command to narrow the latitude and longitude for each map. First create a map that is focused on those samples from the Ryukyu Islands.

# plot all native samples in the Ryukyu Islands
ggplot()+
  geom_polygon(data = pac, aes(x=long, y = lat, group = group), 
               fill="lightgrey", col="black", cex=.1)+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(122, 131), ylim = c(24, 31)) + 
  geom_point(data = sampling.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                     fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.1, w = 0.1), pch=21, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=FALSE) +
  geom_point(data = samplingSANGER.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                           fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.1, w = 0.1), pch=24, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=FALSE) +
  theme_classic()+
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", 
                             "#290AD8", "#FED439", "#B66DFF", 
                             "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                             "#7BA9CB", "#008600"))+
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(3,6))








Save the Ryukyu Islands sampling map as a png file.

# Save the sampling plot
ggsave("ZosteropsSamplingMapRYUKYU.png", device = "png", 
       width = 9, height = 6.5, units = "in", dpi = 500)



Mapping Ogasawara and Volcano Island samples
Because the samples from the Ogasawara and Volcano Islands are isolated geographically and tightly clustered make a separate map for those samples. Many of these islands are tiny and will not show up on the map but rest assured they are there.

# plot all native samples in the Ogasawara and Volcano Islands
ggplot()+
  geom_polygon(data = pac, aes(x=long, y = lat, group = group), 
               fill="lightgrey", 
               col="black", cex=.1)+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(141, 143), ylim = c(24.4, 27.2)) + 
  geom_point(data = sampling.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                     fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.05, w = 0.05), pch=21, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=FALSE) +
  geom_point(data = samplingSANGER.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                           fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.05, w = 0.05), pch=24, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=FALSE) +
  theme_classic()+
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", 
                             "#290AD8", "#FED439", "#B66DFF", 
                             "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                             "#7BA9CB", "#008600"))+
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(3,6))








Save the Ogasawara and Volcano Islands sampling map as a png file.

# Save the sampling plot
ggsave("ZosteropsSamplingMapOGASAWARA.png", device = "png", 
       width = 9, height = 6.5, units = "in", dpi = 500)



Mapping Philippine samples
Many samples across multiple taxa were sampled in the Philippines for this study. Create a separate map that focuses on those samples.

# plot all native samples in the Philippines
ggplot()+
  geom_polygon(data = pac, aes(x=long, y = lat, group = group), 
               fill="lightgrey", 
               col="black", cex=.1)+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(115, 127), ylim = c(6, 20.3)) + 
  geom_point(data = sampling.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                     fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.2, w = 0.2), pch=21, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=FALSE) +
  geom_point(data = samplingSANGER.df, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude, 
                                           fill=Species, size=count), 
             position = position_jitter(h = 0.2, w = 0.2), pch=24, 
             color="black", alpha =0.5, show.legend=FALSE) +
  theme_classic()+
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", 
                             "#290AD8", "#FED439", "#B66DFF", 
                             "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                             "#7BA9CB", "#008600"))+
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(3,6))








Save the Philippine sampling map as a png file.

# Save the sampling plot
ggsave("ZosteropsSamplingMapPHILIPPINES.png", device = "png", 
       width = 9, height = 6.5, units = "in", dpi = 500)

Close log
Close the log file.

log_close()

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text: What follows is our workflow for the Bayesian Phylogenetics and Phylogeography (BP&P or hereafter just BPP) and genealogical diversity index (GDI) analyses for East Asian Zosterops. Using the multispecies coalescent (Flouri et al. 2019), the BPP software package v4.7.0 (Flouri et al. 2018), and the GDI heuristic species delimitation methods outlined in LeachÃ© et al. (LeachÃ© et al. 2018) this analysis attempts to estimate ð and test species hypotheses against the eight locus Sanger sequencing dataset for East Asian Zosterops (see Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees section).

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text: What follows is our workflow for the Bayesian Phylogenetics and Phylogeography (BP&P or hereafter just BPP) and genealogical diversity index (GDI) analyses for East Asian Zosterops. Using the multispecies coalescent (Flouri et al. 2019), the BPP software package v4.7.0 (Flouri et al. 2018), and the GDI heuristic species delimitation methods outlined in LeachÃ© et al. (LeachÃ© et al. 2018) this analysis attempts to estimate ð and test species hypotheses against the eight locus Sanger sequencing dataset for East Asian Zosterops (see Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees section).

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text:
Getting started
We are using R version 4.4.2 and RStudio version 2024.09.1 to illustrate the guide trees in for BPP, calculate GDI, and plot ð and GDI. Quarto version 1.6.39 for Mac OS was used to document the workflow. The analysis was conducted using BPP v4.7.0. The BPP manual is an excellent introduction to these analyses.

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text:
Software and packages

BPP v4.7.0 (Flouri et al. 2018) A newer version of BPP is available but this version appears to work fine. To replicate this analysis, run on an install of BPP v4.7.0 available here. Documentation for BPP is available here.
ape (Paradis and Schliep 2019) The ape package was used to visualize the guide trees used in the BPP analyses.

Load the ape library before proceeding.

library(ape)

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text:
Data files

Sequence alignments
The data used for this analysis will be restricted to those Sanger sequences from Zosterops japonicus, Z. meyeni, Z. montanus, and Z. simplex. The sequence file is in phylip format.
To illustrate the data format an excerpt of the sequence file ZosteropsBPP_JMMSseq.txt is shown below (ellipsis indicates where additional sequences from the original file have been left out). One alignment of individual sequences follows the other sequentially in a single file. A space followed by two numbers indicate the beginning of a locus. First is the number of individual sequences for that locus. Remember that for those loci from phased nuclear coding DNA (nuDNA) there will be two sequences for each individual with the individual identifying code followed by a and b to denote the two phased alleles (see Sanger sequencing summary statistics and trees section). The following number is the length of the sequence alignment in base pairs (bp). Each sequence will lead with the sample, an a for the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) loci or either a or b for the phased cdDNA loci, and underscore, the locus name (e.g.Â COI, ND2, B3GNT9), a ^ symbol, and finally the individual sample name (minus the allelic designations, a and/or b). The individual sample name following the ^ symbol should match the individual names used to map taxon names (i.e.Â the imap file).
