Heredity
The heredity file ZosteropsBPP_heredity.txt below defines the heredity scalars for each locus. Mitochondrial loci have the scalar 0.25 and biparentally inherited nuclear loci have the scalar of 1.0. The scalars in the heredity file are in the the same order as the mtDNA and nuDNA alignments in the sequences file with the two mtDNA loci (COI and ND2) appearing first. Below is the heredity file for all BPP analyses.
0.25
0.25
1
1
1
1
1
1


Taxon maps and guide trees
The final data file needed for these analyses is an imap file saved in txt format that maps the taxon and/or population designations to individual samples. Individual samples in the imap file should match those in the phylip formatted sequence file. Four imap files will be needed for the analysis.

ZosteropsBPPtip_imap.txt
ZosteropsBPPmid1_imap.txt
ZosteropsBPPmid2_imap.txt
ZosteropsBPProot_imap.txt

Codes in these files are designated for each taxon as follows.

Jp - Z. japonicus
Me - Z. meyeni
MoN - Z. montanus Northern Philippines including subspecies halconensis (Mindoro) and whiteheadi (Luzon)
MoS - Z. montanus Southern Philippines, Palawan, and Indonesia including subspecies Z. montanus diuatae (Mindanao), Z. montanus vulcani (Mindanao), Z. montanus pectoralis (Negros), Z. montanus parkesi (Palawan), Z. montanus montanus (Indonesia), and an unnamed Z. montanus population on the Philippine island of Panay.
Si - Z. simplex including populations on the island of Taiwan and Mainland Asia.



Trees

TIP tree
This topology is derived from the single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) dataset analyzed in the Singular Value Decomposition Quartets (SVDQ) package (see SVDQuartets and QAGE section) and the Sanger sequencing dataset analyzed in BEAST2 (see Star BEAST2 section). Branches are color coded here to match the corresponding density distributions in subsequent analyses. Each tree collapses taxa so BPP analyses may estimate ð and ð along each branch.

TIP <- read.tree(text = '((((Jp,Me),MoN),MoS),Si);')
edge_colors <- c("#EEA2AD", "#1E90FF", "#FF8C00", "#D82632", 
                 "#FED439", "#B66DFF", "#FA9C88", "#008600")
plot(TIP, edge.color = edge_colors[1:length(TIP$edge)], 
     edge.width = 4, label.offset = 0.1)
nodes <- c("A", "B", "C", "D")
nodelabels(nodes)
edgelabels()










MID1 tree
Collapses the Z. japonicus and Z. meyeni branches.

MID1 <- read.tree(text = '(((JpMe,MoN),MoS),Si);')
plot(MID1, edge.width = 4, label.offset = 0.1)










MID2 tree
Collapses the Z. japonicus/Z. meyeni branch and Z. montanus from the Northern Philippines.

MID2 <- read.tree(text = '((JpMeMoN,MoS),Si);')
plot(MID2, edge.width = 4, label.offset = 0.1)










ROOT tree
Collapses Z. japonicus, Z. meyeni, Z. motanus in the Northern Philippines, and Z. montanus in Indonesia and the Southern Philippines into a single branch connected to the outgroup (Z. simplex) by a single node.

ROOT <- read.tree(text = '(JpMeMoNMoS,Si);')
plot(ROOT, edge.width = 4, label.offset = 0.1)

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text:
BPP control files
Control files were created to run BPP analyses across a variety of models and prior distributions.

BPP A10 control files
The BPP analyses designated the A runs conduct a species delimitation analysis on a fixed species tree. The species tree used for the A10 runs is the TIP tree with each taxon as a separate branch (Z. japonicus, Z. meyeni, Z. montanus from the Northern Philippines, Z. montanus from the Southern Philippines and Indonesia, and Z. simplex, see above description of associated tree files). Below is the ctl file for the first A series BPP run (A1). Several parameters on the control (ctl) files are edited to execute different runs including the \(Î²_Î¸\) and \(Î²_Ï\) parameters for the inverse ð¤ prior distribution, and the species delimitation model (0 or 1). The \(Î²_Î¸\) and \(Î²_Ï\) parameters for the inverse ð¤ prior distribution are edited at the thetaprior and tauprior lines, each of which is specified by two digits for ð¼ and ð½, but only the ð½ value will be changed across runs. A list of the ctl files and the key parameters for each A series run are shown in the BPP A10 runs table in the A10 results section below. Note that beginning a line in the ctl file with an asterisk causes BPP to ignore that line. Adding and deleting asterisks in front of particular lines of commands is a convenient way to add or delete particular parameters.
seed =  -1
seqfile = ZosteropsBPP_JMMSseq.txt
Imapfile = ZosteropsBPPtip_imap.txt
outfile = ZosteropsBPP_A10_RUNA1.out.txt
mcmcfile = ZosteropsBPP_A10_RUNA1.mcmc.txt

* speciesdelimitation = 0 # fixed species tree
* speciesdelimitation = 1 0 2    # speciesdelimitation algorithm0 and finetune(e)
speciesdelimitation = 1 1 2 1 # speciesdelimitation algorithm1 finetune (a m)
speciestree = 0 0.4 0.2 0.1   # speciestree pSlider ExpandRatio ShrinkRatio

* speciesmodelprior = 1  # 0: uniform LH; 1:uniform rooted trees; 2: uniformSLH; 3: uniformSRooted

species&tree = 5  Jp Me MoN MoS Si
                  93 10 6 25 14
                 ((((Jp, Me), MoN), MoS), Si);
phase = 0    # 0: phased sequences, 1: unphased diploid sequences, in newest version this command is called phase
usedata = 1    # 0: no data (prior); 1:seq like
nloci = 8    # number of data sets in seqfile
model = gtr
alphaprior = 1 1 4
cleandata = 1    # remove sites with ambiguity data (1:yes, 0:no)?

thetaprior = 3 0.01 e  # invgamma(a, b) for theta
tauprior = 3 0.002  # invgamma(a, b) for root tau & Dirichlet(a) for other tau's

locusrate = 1 0 0 1 iid   # (0: No variation, 1: estimate, 2: from file)
heredity = 2 ZosteropsBPP_heredity.txt   # (0: No variation, 1: estimate, 2: from file) & a_gamma b_gamma (if 1)
threads = 8
    
finetune = 1: 8 0.01 0.001 0.01 0.01  # auto (0 or 1): MCMC step lengths, last two values are for lrht and phi which in this run are not estimated so those numbers are excluded, if I wanted to add those estimates I would need two additional finetune values

print = 1 1 0 0   # MCMC samples, locusrate, heredityscalars Genetrees
burnin = 10000
sampfreq = 2
nsample = 100000


BPP A00 control files
The BPP analyses designated the B, C, D, and E runs work from a fixed species tree without the BPP species delimitation analysis. For the B runs the \(Î²_Î¸\) and \(Î²_Ï\) parameters for the inverse ð¤ prior distribution are 0.001 and 0.004 respectively. For the C runs the \(Î²_Î¸\) and \(Î²_Ï\) parameters are 0.002 and 0.004, for the D runs these values are 0.001 and 0.0005, and for the E runs these values are 0.002 and 0.0005. Running BPP independently for different, but reasonable, distributions of ð and ð is used to assess the sensitivity of our estimates to the priors. Note that for all the A00 runs (run series B-E) the speciesdelimitation selections are omitted by being preceded by an asterisk, as is the speciesmodelprior selection. Three replicate runs are done for each combination of ð and ð priors and each species tree (TIP, MID1, MID2, and ROOT, see above). Starting each ctl file with seed = -1 creates a different random number seed for each replicate run. Independent runs for each species tree will be used to estimate ð and ð which will in turn be used to estimate the GDI for each branch (see description of GDI below). Below is an example of a B run control file. A list of the ctl files and the key parameters for each set of runs in the B-E series run are shown in the BPP A00 runs table in the A00 results section below.
seed =  -1
seqfile = ZosteropsBPP_JMMSseq.txt
Imapfile = ZosteropsBPPtip_imap.txt
outfile = ZosteropsBPP_A00_RUNB1.out.txt
mcmcfile = ZosteropsBPP_A00_RUNB1.mcmc.txt

speciesdelimitation = 0 # fixed species tree
* speciesdelimitation = 1 0 2    # speciesdelimitation algorithm0 and finetune(e)
* speciesdelimitation = 1 1 2 1 # speciesdelimitation algorithm1 finetune (a m)
speciestree = 0 0.4 0.2 0.1   # speciestree pSlider ExpandRatio ShrinkRatio

* speciesmodelprior = 1  # 0: uniform LH; 1:uniform rooted trees; 2: uniformSLH; 3: uniformSRooted

species&tree = 5  Jp Me MoN MoS Si
                  93 10 6 25 14
                 ((((Jp, Me), MoN), MoS), Si);
phase = 0    # 0: phased sequences, 1: unphased diploid sequences, in newest version this command is called phase
usedata = 1    # 0: no data (prior); 1:seq like
nloci = 8    # number of data sets in seqfile
model = gtr
alphaprior = 1 1 4
cleandata = 1    # remove sites with ambiguity data (1:yes, 0:no)?

thetaprior = 3 0.001 e  # invgamma(a, b) for theta
tauprior = 3 0.004  # invgamma(a, b) for root tau & Dirichlet(a) for other tau's

locusrate = 1 0 0 1 iid   # (0: No variation, 1: estimate, 2: from file)
heredity = 2 ZosteropsBPP_heredity.txt   # (0: No variation, 1: estimate, 2: from file) & a_gamma b_gamma (if 1)
threads = 8
    
finetune = 1: 8 0.01 0.001 0.01 0.01  # auto (0 or 1): MCMC step lengths, last two values are for lrht and phi which in this run are not estimated so those numbers are excluded, if I wanted to add those estimates I would need two additional finetune values

print = 1 1 0 0   # MCMC samples, locusrate, heredityscalars Genetrees
burnin = 10000
sampfreq = 2
nsample = 100000

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text:
Genealogical diversity index (GDI)
\(2\tau/\theta_A\) is the population divergence time for population \(A\) in coalescent units. One coalescent unit is equal to \(2N_A\) generations where \(N_A\) is the effective population size of \(A\). \(e^{(-2\tau/\theta_A)}\) is the probability that two sequences (\(a_1\) and \(a_2\)) from population \(A\) fail to coalesce before the divergence (ð) of \(A\) from its sister lineage. The GDI is the complementary probability of \(e^{(-2\tau/\theta_A)}\) and reflects the probability that \(a_1\) and \(a_2\) coalesce prior to (going backwards in time) the divergence between population \(A\) and its sister lineage. GDI therefore may be calculated from ð and ð using the following equation (Jackson et al. 2016; LeachÃ© et al. 2018).
\[
GDI = 1 - e^{(-2\tau/\theta_A)}
\]
The BPP A00 analyses will estimate ð and ð along each branch in a given tree and we then use those values to calculate the GDI for each branch.

title: BPP and GDI based species delimitation
text:
Running BPP
Upon installing BPP v4.7.0 a directory will be created containing a bin folder with the BPP application (on Mac OS that directory is bpp-4.7.0-macos-aarch64). To execute a BPP run copy the following needed files to this directory (in this example we will be running the B1 run, an A00 analysis with ctl file ZosteropsA00_RUNB1.bpp.ctl).

ZosteropsA00_RUNB1.bpp.ctl
ZosteropsBPP_JMMSseq.txt
ZosteropsBPP_heredity.txt
ZosteropsBPPtip_imap.txt

The only files that change between runs is the ctl file and the imap file.
Navigate to the BPP directory with the bin folder containing the bpp program.
In the terminal run the following command (make sure the needed files are in the working directory).
bin/bpp --cfile ZosteropsA00_RUNB1.bpp.ctl
Upon completion multiple files will be generated by this analysis.

FigTree.tre This is a tree file generated with ð, ð, and 95% highest posterior density (HPD) for ð as branch lengths based on the tree topology given in the analysis.
Eight sample.txt files, one for each locus in the sequence file (locus.[1-8].sample.txt).
SeedUsed A text file recording the random number seed used for the run.
ZosteropsBPP_A00_RUNB1.mcmc.txt A text file containing the results from the MCMC chain.
ZosteropsBPP_A00_RUNB1.out.txt A text file summarizing the output of the run (for A10 runs this will include whether the analysis supported a split at each node along with the posterior probability of a split). For each run the name of the mcmc and out files will be specified by the ctl file.

Repeat this process for each ctl file and for the A00 runs replicate each run three times. Once each run is complete, copy and organize the results to an appropriate directory.

A10 species delimitation results
In the A10 species delimitation analysis BPP returns a posterior probability for each node in the species tree provided, for this analysis the TIP tree in the file ZosteropsBPPtip_imap.txt. A result of 1 indicates a split at that node was supported and a 0 indicates that a lump was supported for the branches at that node. For all the A10 runs listed in the BPP A10 runs table above a split was supported at every node (1111, see tree below) with a posterior probability of 1.0.

TIP <- read.tree(text = '((((Jp,Me),MoN),MoS),Si);')
edge_colors <- c("#EEA2AD", "#1E90FF", "#FF8C00", "#D82632", 
                 "#FED439", "#B66DFF", "#FA9C88", "#008600")
plot(TIP, edge.color = edge_colors[1:length(TIP$edge)], 
     edge.width = 4, label.offset = 0.1)
nodes <- c("1", "1", "1", "1")
nodelabels(nodes)

Import MCMC data
Import MCMC data from for the BPP runs with ð set at 3 and ð½ for the inverse ð¤ prior distribution set at 0.001 and 0.004 for ð and ð respectively.

# A RUNS are BPP runs under the A10 conditions with species delimitation 
# under a fixed tree.
# B-E RUNS are BPP runs under the A00 conditions with no 
# species delimitation and a fixed tree.
# Each set of runs are done under three replicates, four imap files 
# corresponding to different branches of the tree (tip, mid1, mid2, root), 
# and four different combinations of theta and tau prior distributions.
# Taxon codes for trees: Jp (Z. japonicus), Me (Z. meyeni), 
# MoN (Northern Philippine Z. montanus on Luzon and Mindoro), 
# MoS (Southern Philippine Z. montanus in the Visayas and Mindanao), 
# Si (outgroup, Z. simplex on Mainland Asia and Taiwan)
# Trees for .ctl files...
# B RUNS Tip ((((Jp, Me), MoN), MoS), Si)
# C RUNS Mid1 (((JpMe, MoN), MoS), Si)
# D RUNS Mid2 ((JpMeMoN, MoS), Si)
# E RUNS Root (JpMeMoNMoS, Si)
# Beta values for Theta and Tau...
# Z1 0.001 0.004  Z2 0.002 0.004  Z3 0.001 0.0005  Z4 0.002 0.0005
# Tip B1-3 0.001 0.004 B4-6 0.002 0.004 B7-9 0.001 0.0005 B10-12 0.002 0.0005
# Mid1 C1-3 0.001 0.004 C4-6 0.002 0.004 C7-9 0.001 0.0005 C10-12 0.002 0.0005
# Mid2 D1-3 0.001 0.004 D4-6 0.002 0.004 D7-9 0.001 0.0005 D10-12 0.002 0.0005
# Root E1-3 0.001 0.004 E4-6 0.002 0.004 E7-9 0.001 0.0005 E10-12 0.002 0.0005

#import Zosterops MCMC B-E RUNS 1-3 Theta = 0.001 Tau = 0.004

                        pattern = "ZosteropsBPP_A00_RUNB[1-3].mcmc.txt", 
                        full.names = TRUE)
Z1tipB <- do.call(`rbind`,lapply(Z1tfilesB, read.table, header=T))

Z1m1filesC <- list.files(path = "Data/BPP/Z1ThetaTau", 
                         pattern = "ZosteropsBPP_A00_RUNC[1-3].mcmc.txt", 
                         full.names = TRUE)

                        full.names = TRUE)
Z1rootE <- do.call(`rbind`,lapply(Z1rfilesE, read.table, header=T))

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
What follows is an analysis of the Zosterops single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data from our double digest restriction-site associated DNA (ddRAD) library. This analysis seeks to describe general metrics of diversity and variation in East Asian Zosterops and makes some attempt to assess the utility of these data in clustering individuals by putative taxonomic and population groups.



We are using R version 4.4.2, RStudio version 2024.09.1 for the analysis. Quarto version 1.6.39 for Mac OS was used to document the workflow. Set the working directory in RStudio to one where the vcf.gz zipped data file and a txt file denoting the identity of the samples are accessible.



This analysis requires the following data files.

zost.filtered.snps.vcf.gz The gzipped file containing the filtered SNP data in variant call format (VCF) (see DeRaad et al.Â 2024 for details on creation of the ddRAD library and filtering the SNP dataset) (DeRaad et al. 2024)
ZosteropsPOPS4.txt The text file containing the taxon and locale data for each individual sample in the SNP dataset.




For this run the taxon file we are using is ZosteropsPOPS4.txt containing the following samples. Samples of the migratory Zosterops erythropleurus are from breeding and non-breeding sites. Breeding sites for Z. erythropleurus are denoted RUSSIAb and non-breeding sites from Vietnam and denoted VIETNAMnb with b indicating breeding site samples and nb indicating non-breeding site samples.

Begin the analysis by restarting the R session (Session/Restart R in RStudio), loading the initial package libraries, and starting a log of the analysis. Other package libraries will be loaded as needed in later blocks. The following R packages should be installed using the Tools/Install Packages feature in RStudio.

logr (If you are interested in keeping a log of the analysis.) (Bosak 2024)
vcfR (Knaus and GrÃ¼nwald 2017)
poppr (Kamvar, Tabima, and GrÃ¼nwald 2014)
ape (Paradis and Schliep 2019) (Paradis, Claude, and Strimmer 2004)
adegenet (adgenet is automatically installed along with ape) (T. Jombart 2008)
vegan (Oksanen et al. 2025)
RcolorBrewer (Neuwirth 2022)
popgenstuff (Not available currently in the R package repository in the RStudio drop-down list. To install go here.)
umap (Konopka 2023)
igraph (Csardi and Nepusz 2006)
plotly (Sievert 2020)
htmlwidgets (Vaidyanathan et al. 2023)
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)
tidyr (Wickham, Vaughan, and Girlich 2024)

Extract allelic states from the ZosteropsSNPs from the âgtâ portion of the VCF file and create a new object. Estimate Wu and Wattersonâs ð (Watterson 1975) from this new object using the package popgenstuff (calculation includes only the polymorphic sites).

#Theta W for polymorphic SNPs. Only calculating Theta W for polymorphic sites. 
ZosteropsSNPsgt <- extract.gt(ZosteropsSNPs)
calcThetaW(ZosteropsSNPsgt)

[1] 0.09198321


Define the populations from a tab delimited (\t) text file and confirm that the sample names match those in the VCF file.

# Define taxa and populations from tab delimited (\t) text file with a header and confirm sample names match the VCF file.
ZosteropsPOPs <- read.table("Data/Taxon files/ZosteropsPOPS4.txt", sep = "\t", header = TRUE)
all(colnames(ZosteropsSNPs@gt)[-1] == ZosteropsPOPs$SAMPLE)

[1] TRUE


Convert the ZosteropsSNPs VCF object to a genlight (gl) object, indicate the ploidy (2 for diploid), and assign taxa to the genlight object using ZosteropsPOPs and the TAXON column (ZosteropsPOPs$TAXON).

# Convert to genlight object, determine ploidy, and assign taxa to genlight object.
gl.ZosteropsSNPs <- vcfR2genlight(ZosteropsSNPs)
ploidy(gl.ZosteropsSNPs) <- 2
pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs) <- ZosteropsPOPs$TAXON




Define the color schema to be used throughout the figures for each taxon.

ColorPal_CUSTOM <- c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", "#290AD8", "#FED439", 
                     "#B66DFF", "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                     "#7BA9CB", "#008600")




Create a minimum spanning network (MSN). Export the figure as either a pdf or png file using the export function in RStudio. Beginning here we will set a different random seed for each operation where a seed is required. Setting inds to some set of characters not in the dataset (in this instance just a blank space) and nodelab to some arbitrarily large number in plot_poppr_msn will leave blank points on the network. Removing these arguments will result in each point on the network labeled with the corresponding sample name.

MSNseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(MSNseed)

[1] 661

set.seed(MSNseed)
ZosteropsSNPsDist <- bitwise.dist(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
ZosteropsSNPsMSN <- poppr.msn(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, ZosteropsSNPsDist, showplot = FALSE, include.ties = TRUE)
node.size <- rep(2, times = nInd(gl.ZosteropsSNPs))
names(node.size) <- indNames(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
vertex.attributes(ZosteropsSNPsMSN$graph)$size <- node.size
plot_poppr_msn(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, ZosteropsSNPsMSN, palette = ColorPal_CUSTOM, gadj = 70, label.cex = 8, pop.leg = TRUE, size.leg = FALSE, inds = "", nodelab = 100000, )











Create a distance tree based on the unweighted pair group method with arithmetic mean (UPGMA). Export the figure as either a pdf or png file using the export function in RStudio.

ZosteropsSNPsDTree <- aboot(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, tree = "upgma", distance = bitwise.dist, sample = 100, showtree = FALSE, cutoff = 50, quiet = FALSE)


Running bootstraps:       100 / 100
Calculating bootstrap values... done.

plot.phylo(ZosteropsSNPsDTree, cex = 1, font = 2, adj = 0)
nodelabels(ZosteropsSNPsDTree$node.label, adj = c(1.3, -0.5), frame = "n", cex = 1.3,font = 3, xpd = TRUE)
axis(side = 1, cex.axis = 2)
title(xlab = "Genetic distance (proportion of loci that are different)", cex.lab = 2)











Conduct a principal component analysis (PCA) on the gl.ZosteropsSNPs object. Graph the percent of variance explained by each principal component (PC) and create two PC plots; one plot with PC1 and PC2 and a three-dimensional plot with PC1, PC2, and PC3.

PCAseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(PCAseed)

[1] 135

set.seed(PCAseed)
ZosteropsSNPsPCA <- glPca(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, nf = 5)
ZosteropsSNPs_PCA_VARexp <- (100*ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig/sum(ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig))
barplot(100*ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig/sum(ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig), col = heat.colors(200), main = "PCA Eigenvalues", ylim = c(0,30), cex.axis = 1.4)
title(ylab = "Percent of variance explained", line =2, cex.lab = 1.4)
title(xlab = "Eigenvalues", line = 2, cex.lab = 1.4)







ZosteropsSNPsPCAscores <- as.data.frame(ZosteropsSNPsPCA$scores)
ZosteropsSNPsPCAscores$pop <- pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
PCAplot <- ZosteropsSNPsPCAscores
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="erythropleurus"] <- "Z. erythropleurus"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="everetti"] <- "Z. everetti"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="japonicus"] <- "Z. japonicus"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="japonicus_alani"] <- "Z. japonicus alani"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="meyeni"] <- "Z. meyeni"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="montanus_NORTH"] <- "Z. montanus N. PHILIPPINES"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="montanus_PALAWAN"] <- "Z. montanus PALAWAN"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="montanus_SOUTH"] <- "Z. montanus S. PHILIPPINES"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="nigrorum"] <- "Z. nigrorum"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="palpebrosus"] <- "Z. palpebrosus"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="simplex"] <- "Z. simplex"
names(PCAplot)[names(PCAplot)=="pop"]  <- "Taxon"
PC2Dplot <- plot_ly(x = PCAplot$PC1, y = PCAplot$PC2, type = "scatter", mode = 'markers',
        marker = list(size = 10, line = list(width = 1, color = 'black')),
        color = PCAplot$Taxon, 
        colors = ColorPal_CUSTOM) %>%
  layout(xaxis = list(title = 'PC1'), yaxis = list(title = 'PC2'))
PC3Dplot <- plot_ly(x = PCAplot$PC1, y = PCAplot$PC2, z = PCAplot$PC3, type = "scatter3d", mode = 'markers', 
        marker = list(size = 10, line = list(width = 1, color = 'black')),
        color = PCAplot$Taxon, 
        colors = ColorPal_CUSTOM) %>%
  layout(scene = list(xaxis = list(title = 'PC1'),
                      yaxis = list(title = 'PC2'),
                      zaxis = list(title = 'PC3')))
PC2Dplot




PC3Dplot




ZosteropsSNPs_PCA_VARexp[1:5]

[1] 29.581302 16.282986  7.692618  6.388801  5.459259


Calculate the centroids for each group based on the first three principal components and the pairwise Euclidean distances between each pair of groups.

Zosterops_PCAscores <- ZosteropsSNPsPCA$scores[, 1:3]
Zosterops_PCAgroups <- gl.ZosteropsSNPs@pop
Zosterops_PCAdf <- data.frame(Zosterops_PCAscores, Group = Zosterops_PCAgroups)
Zosterops_unique_PCAgroups <- unique(Zosterops_PCAgroups)
Zosterops_PCAcentroids <- data.frame(Group = character(), PC1 = numeric(), PC2 = numeric(), PC3 = numeric(), PC4 = numeric(), PC5 = numeric(), stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
# Loop through each unique group to calculate centroids
for (group in Zosterops_unique_PCAgroups) {
  group_scores <- Zosterops_PCAdf[Zosterops_PCAdf$Group == group, 1:3]
  centroid <- colMeans(group_scores, na.rm = TRUE)
  Zosterops_PCAcentroids <- rbind(Zosterops_PCAcentroids, 
                                   data.frame(Group = group, 
                                              PC1 = centroid[1], 
                                              PC2 = centroid[2], 
                                              PC3 = centroid[3]))
}
print(Zosterops_PCAcentroids)

Zosterops_PCAdistance_matrix <- as.matrix(dist(Zosterops_PCAcentroids[, 2:4]))
Zosterops_PCAdistance_df <- as.data.frame(Zosterops_PCAdistance_matrix)
rownames(Zosterops_PCAdistance_df) <- Zosterops_PCAcentroids$Group
colnames(Zosterops_PCAdistance_df) <- Zosterops_PCAcentroids$Group
print(Zosterops_PCAdistance_df)

# Plot PCA scores
Zosterops_PCAcentroids_plot <- ggplot(Zosterops_PCAdf, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = Group)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +  # Add points for PCA scores
  geom_point(data = Zosterops_PCAcentroids, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2), 
             color = "black", size = 3, shape = 3) +  # Add centroids
  labs(title = "PCA of Zosterops SNPs", x = "PC1", y = "PC2") +
  scale_color_manual(values = ColorPal_CUSTOM) +
  theme_minimal()

# Display the plot

# Export PC3Dplot as html using the htmlWidgets package or from the menu in the RStudio viewer.
saveWidget(ggplotly(PC2Dplot), file = "Zosterops2DPCAplot.html")
saveWidget(ggplotly(PC3Dplot), file = "Zosterops3DPCAplot.html")




Uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP) (âUniform Manifold Approximation and Projectionâ 2024) is a non-linear, stochastic algorithm to reduce dimensionality for visualization of multivariate data. UMAP seeks to preserve as much of the relationships among groups in the dataset as possible while reducing to a minimal number of components. In this case we are visualizing the SNP data with UMAP for two and three dimensions using the umap package and plotting the results for each analysis using the plot_ly command from the plotly package. The n_neighbors, min_dist, and metric arguments all reflect the default values. For each plot save as html files using the saveWidget command in the htmlwidgets package.

# Set random seed
UMAPseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(UMAPseed)

[1] 1

set.seed(UMAPseed)

# Define color palette
ColorPal_UMAP <- c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", "#290AD8", "#FED439", 
                     "#B66DFF", "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                     "#7BA9CB", "#008600")

# Extract SNP data
ZosteropsSNPs_UMAP <- as.data.frame(tab(gl.ZosteropsSNPs))  # Use tab() to get the SNP data

ZosteropsUMAP_results <- umap(ZosteropsSNPs_UMAP, n_neighbors = 15, min_dist = 0.1, metric = 'euclidean')
ZosteropsUMAP_df <- as.data.frame(ZosteropsUMAP_results$layout)
ZosteropsUMAP_df$Taxon <- pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)  # Add population information
ZosteropsUMAP_2Dplot <- plot_ly(data = ZosteropsUMAP_df, x = ~V1, y = ~V2, type = 'scatter', mode = 'markers',
                     marker = list(size = 15, line = list(width = 1, color = 'black')),
                     color = ~Taxon, colors = ColorPal_UMAP) %>%
  layout(xaxis = list(title = 'UMAP 1'),
         yaxis = list(title = 'UMAP 2'))

saveWidget(ggplotly(ZosteropsUMAP_2Dplot), file = "ZosteropsUMAP_2Dplot.html")
saveWidget(ggplotly(ZosteropsUMAP_3Dplot), file = "ZosteropsUMAP_3Dplot.html")






Discriminant analysis of principal components (DAPC) is a multivariate method that takes principal components (PCs) and partitions variance into within- and among-group components in a way that maximizes discrimination among the groups (Thibaut Jombart, Devillard, and Balloux 2010). DAPC makes no explicit assumptions regarding recombination or panmixia. This allows use of the full SNP dataset without worrying about filtering to reduce the likelihood of linkage as is required for STRUCTURE or ADMIXTURE. A tutorial on DAPC is available here. First conduct a cross-validation analysis to help determine the optimal number of PCs to be retained in the DAPC. Test between 1 and 50 PCs (n.pca = 1:50) with 100 replicate runs per PC (n.rep = 100) of the cross-validation analysis. Use the multicore option and 6 CPUs (ncpus = 6L), or potentially more if your machine allows it. Even running multiple cores this run can take a while to execute. Executing this analysis within the system.time command will return an elapsed time for the operation. This will return a graph showing the proportion of successful group predictions on the y-axis and the results from the individual replicate runs for each PC on the x-axis.

DAPCseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(DAPCseed)

[1] 836

set.seed(DAPCseed)
system.time (ZosteropsSNPsDAPCpramx <- xvalDapc(tab(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, NA.method = "mean"), pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs), n.pca = 1:50, n.rep = 100, parallel = "multicore", ncpus = 6L))








    user   system  elapsed 
1686.290  271.423  361.423 





The DAPC cross validation provides some clues as to where we no longer need to add PCs to the DAPC to get increased discrimination, but we want to know exactly how many PCs is optimum for discrimination. The a-score is the difference between the proportion of successful reassignments using the real groups and assignments into randomly assigned groups. Thus the average a-score is the average percent improvement in discrimination over that based on random groupings. The code below will estimate the a-score across 30 replicate runs (n.sim = 30) and 40 PCs (n.pca = 40) showing the result per group for each run, the average across all replicates per group, and the overall average.

ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM <- dapc(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, n.pca = 40, n.da = nPop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)-1)
a.score(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM, n.pca = 1:ncol(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM$tab), n=30, plot = FALSE, n.sim = 30)

To get an optimal number of PCs for the DAPC iterate the calculation of the a-score across 100 replicate runs and for each, graph the distribution of the a-score for each number of PCs.
ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM_RESULTS <- list()
for(i in 1:100) {
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM_RESULTS[[i]] <- optim.a.score(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM)
}
































































































































































































































































































































































Across 100 replicate runs of our iterated a-score calculation print the optimal number of PCs for each run. In each run the optimal number of PCs is that which maximizes the a-score.

OptimumPC_list <- vector("list", 100)
for(i in 1:100) {
  OptimumPC <- ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM_RESULTS[[i]]$best
  print(OptimumPC)
  OptimumPC_list[[i]] <- OptimumPC
}

Produce a summary of the 100 iterated a-score estimates denoting the minimum and maximum number of optimal PCs across all runs as well as the median and mean optimal PCs and first and third quartiles. Use the median optimal number of PCs as a starting point in subsequent DAPC analyses.

write.table(OptimumPC_list, file = "OptimumPC_results_n100.txt", row.names = FALSE, col.names = FALSE)
OptimumPC_list <- unlist(OptimumPC_list)
OptimumPC_list_summary <- summary(OptimumPC_list)
OptimumPC_list_summary

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   7.00    8.00    8.00   11.54   11.75   24.00 





Conduct the final DAPC analysis with group assignments for each individual sample. Three runs will be repeated for this analysis. One of those runs uses the optimal number of PCs from the prior iterated a-score estimations (the median optimal number of PCs across 100 replicate runs of the optimal a-score estimation). The other two runs of the DAPC analysis are four PCs less than the optimal and four PCs greater than the optimal number of PCs. Generate a scatter plot from the DAPC analysis and a bar plot showing the probability of assignment for each individual sample. Save both the scatter plot and bar graphs as pdf files and generate a tab-delimited table of the results for each individual sample with the columns being the original assigned population, the sample, the population assigned by the DAPC, and the posterior probability of that particular assignment. In addition, for each replicate run generate a loading plot displaying how each SNP contributes to the PCs for the optimal number of PCs and four less than and four greater than the optimal number. Export each loading plot as a pdf.

n.pca.values <- c(4, 8, 12)
for (n.pca in n.pca.values) {
  DAPCseed = sample(1:999, 1)
  print(DAPCseed)
  set.seed(DAPCseed)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPC <- dapc(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, n.pca = n.pca, n.da = nPop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)-1)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_contributions <- loadingplot(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC$var.contr, axis = 2, thres = 0.0025, lab.jitter = 1)
  DAPCscatter <- scatter(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC, col = ColorPal_CUSTOM, cex = 3, legend = TRUE, clabel = F, posi.leg = "bottomleft", scree.pca = TRUE,
          posi.pca = "topright", cleg = 0.75)
  DAPCscatter
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults <- as.data.frame(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC$posterior)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults$pop <- pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults$indNames <- rownames(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults <- pivot_longer(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, -c(pop, indNames))
  head(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, n = 11)
  nPCAtitle <- paste(n.pca, "principal components")
  print(nPCAtitle)
  colnames(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults) <- c("Original_Pop","Sample","Assigned_Pop","Posterior_membership_probability")
  DAPCbar <- ggplot(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, aes(x=Sample, y=Posterior_membership_probability, fill=Assigned_Pop))
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + geom_bar(stat='identity') 
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + ggtitle(nPCAtitle)
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + scale_fill_manual(values = ColorPal_CUSTOM) 
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + facet_grid(~Original_Pop, scales = "free")
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, size = 8))
  print(DAPCbar)
  write.table(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, file = paste("ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults","_",n.pca,"PCs.txt"), row.names = FALSE, sep = "\t", quote = FALSE)
}

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text: What follows is an analysis of the Zosterops single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data from our double digest restriction-site associated DNA (ddRAD) library. This analysis seeks to describe general metrics of diversity and variation in East Asian Zosterops and makes some attempt to assess the utility of these data in clustering individuals by putative taxonomic and population groups.

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text: We are using R version 4.4.2, RStudio version 2024.09.1 for the analysis. Quarto version 1.6.39 for Mac OS was used to document the workflow. Set the working directory in RStudio to one where the vcf.gz zipped data file and a txt file denoting the identity of the samples are accessible.

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
This analysis requires the following data files.

zost.filtered.snps.vcf.gz The gzipped file containing the filtered SNP data in variant call format (VCF) (see DeRaad et al.Â 2024 for details on creation of the ddRAD library and filtering the SNP dataset) (DeRaad et al. 2024)
ZosteropsPOPS4.txt The text file containing the taxon and locale data for each individual sample in the SNP dataset.

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
For this run the taxon file we are using is ZosteropsPOPS4.txt containing the following samples. Samples of the migratory Zosterops erythropleurus are from breeding and non-breeding sites. Breeding sites for Z. erythropleurus are denoted RUSSIAb and non-breeding sites from Vietnam and denoted VIETNAMnb with b indicating breeding site samples and nb indicating non-breeding site samples.

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Begin the analysis by restarting the R session (Session/Restart R in RStudio), loading the initial package libraries, and starting a log of the analysis. Other package libraries will be loaded as needed in later blocks. The following R packages should be installed using the Tools/Install Packages feature in RStudio.

logr (If you are interested in keeping a log of the analysis.) (Bosak 2024)
vcfR (Knaus and GrÃ¼nwald 2017)
poppr (Kamvar, Tabima, and GrÃ¼nwald 2014)
ape (Paradis and Schliep 2019) (Paradis, Claude, and Strimmer 2004)
adegenet (adgenet is automatically installed along with ape) (T. Jombart 2008)
vegan (Oksanen et al. 2025)
RcolorBrewer (Neuwirth 2022)
popgenstuff (Not available currently in the R package repository in the RStudio drop-down list. To install go here.)
umap (Konopka 2023)
igraph (Csardi and Nepusz 2006)
plotly (Sievert 2020)
htmlwidgets (Vaidyanathan et al. 2023)
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)
tidyr (Wickham, Vaughan, and Girlich 2024)

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Load the filtered VCF dataset from a compressed gzipped (gz) file.

# Load SNPs from VCF file
ZosteropsSNPs <- read.vcfR("Data/VCF files/zost.filtered.snps.vcf.gz")

Extract allelic states from the ZosteropsSNPs from the âgtâ portion of the VCF file and create a new object. Estimate Wu and Wattersonâs ð (Watterson 1975) from this new object using the package popgenstuff (calculation includes only the polymorphic sites).

#Theta W for polymorphic SNPs. Only calculating Theta W for polymorphic sites. 
ZosteropsSNPsgt <- extract.gt(ZosteropsSNPs)
calcThetaW(ZosteropsSNPsgt)

[1] 0.09198321


Define the populations from a tab delimited (\t) text file and confirm that the sample names match those in the VCF file.

# Define taxa and populations from tab delimited (\t) text file with a header and confirm sample names match the VCF file.
ZosteropsPOPs <- read.table("Data/Taxon files/ZosteropsPOPS4.txt", sep = "\t", header = TRUE)
all(colnames(ZosteropsSNPs@gt)[-1] == ZosteropsPOPs$SAMPLE)

[1] TRUE


Convert the ZosteropsSNPs VCF object to a genlight (gl) object, indicate the ploidy (2 for diploid), and assign taxa to the genlight object using ZosteropsPOPs and the TAXON column (ZosteropsPOPs$TAXON).

# Convert to genlight object, determine ploidy, and assign taxa to genlight object.
gl.ZosteropsSNPs <- vcfR2genlight(ZosteropsSNPs)
ploidy(gl.ZosteropsSNPs) <- 2
pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs) <- ZosteropsPOPs$TAXON

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Define the color schema to be used throughout the figures for each taxon.

ColorPal_CUSTOM <- c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", "#290AD8", "#FED439", 
                     "#B66DFF", "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                     "#7BA9CB", "#008600")

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Create a minimum spanning network (MSN). Export the figure as either a pdf or png file using the export function in RStudio. Beginning here we will set a different random seed for each operation where a seed is required. Setting inds to some set of characters not in the dataset (in this instance just a blank space) and nodelab to some arbitrarily large number in plot_poppr_msn will leave blank points on the network. Removing these arguments will result in each point on the network labeled with the corresponding sample name.

MSNseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(MSNseed)

[1] 661

set.seed(MSNseed)
ZosteropsSNPsDist <- bitwise.dist(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
ZosteropsSNPsMSN <- poppr.msn(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, ZosteropsSNPsDist, showplot = FALSE, include.ties = TRUE)
node.size <- rep(2, times = nInd(gl.ZosteropsSNPs))
names(node.size) <- indNames(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
vertex.attributes(ZosteropsSNPsMSN$graph)$size <- node.size
plot_poppr_msn(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, ZosteropsSNPsMSN, palette = ColorPal_CUSTOM, gadj = 70, label.cex = 8, pop.leg = TRUE, size.leg = FALSE, inds = "", nodelab = 100000, )

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Create a distance tree based on the unweighted pair group method with arithmetic mean (UPGMA). Export the figure as either a pdf or png file using the export function in RStudio.

ZosteropsSNPsDTree <- aboot(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, tree = "upgma", distance = bitwise.dist, sample = 100, showtree = FALSE, cutoff = 50, quiet = FALSE)


Running bootstraps:       100 / 100
Calculating bootstrap values... done.

plot.phylo(ZosteropsSNPsDTree, cex = 1, font = 2, adj = 0)
nodelabels(ZosteropsSNPsDTree$node.label, adj = c(1.3, -0.5), frame = "n", cex = 1.3,font = 3, xpd = TRUE)
axis(side = 1, cex.axis = 2)
title(xlab = "Genetic distance (proportion of loci that are different)", cex.lab = 2)

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Conduct a principal component analysis (PCA) on the gl.ZosteropsSNPs object. Graph the percent of variance explained by each principal component (PC) and create two PC plots; one plot with PC1 and PC2 and a three-dimensional plot with PC1, PC2, and PC3.

PCAseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(PCAseed)

[1] 135

set.seed(PCAseed)
ZosteropsSNPsPCA <- glPca(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, nf = 5)
ZosteropsSNPs_PCA_VARexp <- (100*ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig/sum(ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig))
barplot(100*ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig/sum(ZosteropsSNPsPCA$eig), col = heat.colors(200), main = "PCA Eigenvalues", ylim = c(0,30), cex.axis = 1.4)
title(ylab = "Percent of variance explained", line =2, cex.lab = 1.4)
title(xlab = "Eigenvalues", line = 2, cex.lab = 1.4)







ZosteropsSNPsPCAscores <- as.data.frame(ZosteropsSNPsPCA$scores)
ZosteropsSNPsPCAscores$pop <- pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
PCAplot <- ZosteropsSNPsPCAscores
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="erythropleurus"] <- "Z. erythropleurus"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="everetti"] <- "Z. everetti"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="japonicus"] <- "Z. japonicus"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="japonicus_alani"] <- "Z. japonicus alani"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="meyeni"] <- "Z. meyeni"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="montanus_NORTH"] <- "Z. montanus N. PHILIPPINES"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="montanus_PALAWAN"] <- "Z. montanus PALAWAN"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="montanus_SOUTH"] <- "Z. montanus S. PHILIPPINES"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="nigrorum"] <- "Z. nigrorum"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="palpebrosus"] <- "Z. palpebrosus"
levels(PCAplot$pop)[levels(PCAplot$pop)=="simplex"] <- "Z. simplex"
names(PCAplot)[names(PCAplot)=="pop"]  <- "Taxon"
PC2Dplot <- plot_ly(x = PCAplot$PC1, y = PCAplot$PC2, type = "scatter", mode = 'markers',
        marker = list(size = 10, line = list(width = 1, color = 'black')),
        color = PCAplot$Taxon, 
        colors = ColorPal_CUSTOM) %>%
  layout(xaxis = list(title = 'PC1'), yaxis = list(title = 'PC2'))
PC3Dplot <- plot_ly(x = PCAplot$PC1, y = PCAplot$PC2, z = PCAplot$PC3, type = "scatter3d", mode = 'markers', 
        marker = list(size = 10, line = list(width = 1, color = 'black')),
        color = PCAplot$Taxon, 
        colors = ColorPal_CUSTOM) %>%
  layout(scene = list(xaxis = list(title = 'PC1'),
                      yaxis = list(title = 'PC2'),
                      zaxis = list(title = 'PC3')))
PC2Dplot




PC3Dplot




ZosteropsSNPs_PCA_VARexp[1:5]

[1] 29.581302 16.282986  7.692618  6.388801  5.459259


Calculate the centroids for each group based on the first three principal components and the pairwise Euclidean distances between each pair of groups.

Zosterops_PCAscores <- ZosteropsSNPsPCA$scores[, 1:3]
Zosterops_PCAgroups <- gl.ZosteropsSNPs@pop
Zosterops_PCAdf <- data.frame(Zosterops_PCAscores, Group = Zosterops_PCAgroups)
Zosterops_unique_PCAgroups <- unique(Zosterops_PCAgroups)
Zosterops_PCAcentroids <- data.frame(Group = character(), PC1 = numeric(), PC2 = numeric(), PC3 = numeric(), PC4 = numeric(), PC5 = numeric(), stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
# Loop through each unique group to calculate centroids
for (group in Zosterops_unique_PCAgroups) {
  group_scores <- Zosterops_PCAdf[Zosterops_PCAdf$Group == group, 1:3]
  centroid <- colMeans(group_scores, na.rm = TRUE)
  Zosterops_PCAcentroids <- rbind(Zosterops_PCAcentroids, 
                                   data.frame(Group = group, 
                                              PC1 = centroid[1], 
                                              PC2 = centroid[2], 
                                              PC3 = centroid[3]))
}
print(Zosterops_PCAcentroids)

# Plot PCA scores
Zosterops_PCAcentroids_plot <- ggplot(Zosterops_PCAdf, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = Group)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +  # Add points for PCA scores
  geom_point(data = Zosterops_PCAcentroids, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2), 
             color = "black", size = 3, shape = 3) +  # Add centroids
  labs(title = "PCA of Zosterops SNPs", x = "PC1", y = "PC2") +
  scale_color_manual(values = ColorPal_CUSTOM) +
  theme_minimal()

# Display the plot
print(Zosterops_PCAcentroids_plot)








Export both the two principal components and three principal components plots (PC2Dplot and PC3Dplot) as html widgets.

# Export PC3Dplot as html using the htmlWidgets package or from the menu in the RStudio viewer.
saveWidget(ggplotly(PC2Dplot), file = "Zosterops2DPCAplot.html")
saveWidget(ggplotly(PC3Dplot), file = "Zosterops3DPCAplot.html")

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP) (âUniform Manifold Approximation and Projectionâ 2024) is a non-linear, stochastic algorithm to reduce dimensionality for visualization of multivariate data. UMAP seeks to preserve as much of the relationships among groups in the dataset as possible while reducing to a minimal number of components. In this case we are visualizing the SNP data with UMAP for two and three dimensions using the umap package and plotting the results for each analysis using the plot_ly command from the plotly package. The n_neighbors, min_dist, and metric arguments all reflect the default values. For each plot save as html files using the saveWidget command in the htmlwidgets package.

# Set random seed
UMAPseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(UMAPseed)

[1] 1

set.seed(UMAPseed)

# Define color palette
ColorPal_UMAP <- c("#004949", "#DB6D00", "#D82632", "#290AD8", "#FED439", 
                     "#B66DFF", "#006DDB", "#FA9C88", "#924900", 
                     "#7BA9CB", "#008600")

# Extract SNP data
ZosteropsSNPs_UMAP <- as.data.frame(tab(gl.ZosteropsSNPs))  # Use tab() to get the SNP data

ZosteropsUMAP_results <- umap(ZosteropsSNPs_UMAP, n_neighbors = 15, min_dist = 0.1, metric = 'euclidean')
ZosteropsUMAP_df <- as.data.frame(ZosteropsUMAP_results$layout)
ZosteropsUMAP_df$Taxon <- pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)  # Add population information
ZosteropsUMAP_2Dplot <- plot_ly(data = ZosteropsUMAP_df, x = ~V1, y = ~V2, type = 'scatter', mode = 'markers',
                     marker = list(size = 15, line = list(width = 1, color = 'black')),
                     color = ~Taxon, colors = ColorPal_UMAP) %>%
  layout(xaxis = list(title = 'UMAP 1'),
         yaxis = list(title = 'UMAP 2'))
ZosteropsUMAP_2Dplot

title: Distance trees, PCA, UMAP, and DAPC analyses
text:
Discriminant analysis of principal components (DAPC) is a multivariate method that takes principal components (PCs) and partitions variance into within- and among-group components in a way that maximizes discrimination among the groups (Thibaut Jombart, Devillard, and Balloux 2010). DAPC makes no explicit assumptions regarding recombination or panmixia. This allows use of the full SNP dataset without worrying about filtering to reduce the likelihood of linkage as is required for STRUCTURE or ADMIXTURE. A tutorial on DAPC is available here. First conduct a cross-validation analysis to help determine the optimal number of PCs to be retained in the DAPC. Test between 1 and 50 PCs (n.pca = 1:50) with 100 replicate runs per PC (n.rep = 100) of the cross-validation analysis. Use the multicore option and 6 CPUs (ncpus = 6L), or potentially more if your machine allows it. Even running multiple cores this run can take a while to execute. Executing this analysis within the system.time command will return an elapsed time for the operation. This will return a graph showing the proportion of successful group predictions on the y-axis and the results from the individual replicate runs for each PC on the x-axis.

DAPCseed = sample(1:999, 1)
print(DAPCseed)

[1] 836

set.seed(DAPCseed)
system.time (ZosteropsSNPsDAPCpramx <- xvalDapc(tab(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, NA.method = "mean"), pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs), n.pca = 1:50, n.rep = 100, parallel = "multicore", ncpus = 6L))








    user   system  elapsed 
1686.290  271.423  361.423 





The DAPC cross validation provides some clues as to where we no longer need to add PCs to the DAPC to get increased discrimination, but we want to know exactly how many PCs is optimum for discrimination. The a-score is the difference between the proportion of successful reassignments using the real groups and assignments into randomly assigned groups. Thus the average a-score is the average percent improvement in discrimination over that based on random groupings. The code below will estimate the a-score across 30 replicate runs (n.sim = 30) and 40 PCs (n.pca = 40) showing the result per group for each run, the average across all replicates per group, and the overall average.

ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM <- dapc(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, n.pca = 40, n.da = nPop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)-1)
a.score(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM, n.pca = 1:ncol(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM$tab), n=30, plot = FALSE, n.sim = 30)

To get an optimal number of PCs for the DAPC iterate the calculation of the a-score across 100 replicate runs and for each, graph the distribution of the a-score for each number of PCs.
ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM_RESULTS <- list()
for(i in 1:100) {
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM_RESULTS[[i]] <- optim.a.score(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM)
}
































































































































































































































































































































































Across 100 replicate runs of our iterated a-score calculation print the optimal number of PCs for each run. In each run the optimal number of PCs is that which maximizes the a-score.

OptimumPC_list <- vector("list", 100)
for(i in 1:100) {
  OptimumPC <- ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_OPTIMUM_RESULTS[[i]]$best
  print(OptimumPC)
  OptimumPC_list[[i]] <- OptimumPC
}

Produce a summary of the 100 iterated a-score estimates denoting the minimum and maximum number of optimal PCs across all runs as well as the median and mean optimal PCs and first and third quartiles. Use the median optimal number of PCs as a starting point in subsequent DAPC analyses.

write.table(OptimumPC_list, file = "OptimumPC_results_n100.txt", row.names = FALSE, col.names = FALSE)
OptimumPC_list <- unlist(OptimumPC_list)
OptimumPC_list_summary <- summary(OptimumPC_list)
OptimumPC_list_summary

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   7.00    8.00    8.00   11.54   11.75   24.00 





Conduct the final DAPC analysis with group assignments for each individual sample. Three runs will be repeated for this analysis. One of those runs uses the optimal number of PCs from the prior iterated a-score estimations (the median optimal number of PCs across 100 replicate runs of the optimal a-score estimation). The other two runs of the DAPC analysis are four PCs less than the optimal and four PCs greater than the optimal number of PCs. Generate a scatter plot from the DAPC analysis and a bar plot showing the probability of assignment for each individual sample. Save both the scatter plot and bar graphs as pdf files and generate a tab-delimited table of the results for each individual sample with the columns being the original assigned population, the sample, the population assigned by the DAPC, and the posterior probability of that particular assignment. In addition, for each replicate run generate a loading plot displaying how each SNP contributes to the PCs for the optimal number of PCs and four less than and four greater than the optimal number. Export each loading plot as a pdf.

n.pca.values <- c(4, 8, 12)
for (n.pca in n.pca.values) {
  DAPCseed = sample(1:999, 1)
  print(DAPCseed)
  set.seed(DAPCseed)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPC <- dapc(gl.ZosteropsSNPs, n.pca = n.pca, n.da = nPop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)-1)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPC_contributions <- loadingplot(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC$var.contr, axis = 2, thres = 0.0025, lab.jitter = 1)
  DAPCscatter <- scatter(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC, col = ColorPal_CUSTOM, cex = 3, legend = TRUE, clabel = F, posi.leg = "bottomleft", scree.pca = TRUE,
          posi.pca = "topright", cleg = 0.75)
  DAPCscatter
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults <- as.data.frame(ZosteropsSNPsDAPC$posterior)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults$pop <- pop(gl.ZosteropsSNPs)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults$indNames <- rownames(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults)
  ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults <- pivot_longer(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, -c(pop, indNames))
  head(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, n = 11)
  nPCAtitle <- paste(n.pca, "principal components")
  print(nPCAtitle)
  colnames(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults) <- c("Original_Pop","Sample","Assigned_Pop","Posterior_membership_probability")
  DAPCbar <- ggplot(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, aes(x=Sample, y=Posterior_membership_probability, fill=Assigned_Pop))
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + geom_bar(stat='identity') 
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + ggtitle(nPCAtitle)
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + scale_fill_manual(values = ColorPal_CUSTOM) 
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + facet_grid(~Original_Pop, scales = "free")
  DAPCbar <-  DAPCbar + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, size = 8))
  print(DAPCbar)
  write.table(ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults, file = paste("ZosteropsSNPsDAPCResults","_",n.pca,"PCs.txt"), row.names = FALSE, sep = "\t", quote = FALSE)
}

Close the log file.

title: Genetic differentiation and biogeographic breaks
text: What follows is our workflow for estimating genetic distance and differentiation among East Asian and Philippine Zosterops populations and across biogeographic breaks based on single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data from our double digest restriction-site associated DNA (ddRAD) library.

title: Genetic differentiation and biogeographic breaks
text: What follows is our workflow for estimating genetic distance and differentiation among East Asian and Philippine Zosterops populations and across biogeographic breaks based on single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data from our double digest restriction-site associated DNA (ddRAD) library.

title: Genetic differentiation and biogeographic breaks
text:
Getting started
We are using R version 4.4.2, RStudio version 2024.09.1 for the analysis. Quarto version 1.6.39 for Mac OS was used to document the workflow. Set the working directory in RStudio to one where the vcf file for the SNPs and a text file defining the population for each sample are available.

Packages
Set the working directory to one where the SNP data file zost.filtered.snps.vcf and the taxon/population designation file ZosteropsPOPS_distance.txt are both accessible. Conducting the distance and Fst analysis on these data and generating the associated figures and maps requires the following R packages.

logr (Bosak 2024) Optional if you wish to create a log file for the analysis.
vcfR (Knaus and GrÃ¼nwald 2017)
SNPfiltR (DeRaad 2023)
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)
adegenet (Jombart 2008)
StAMPP (Pembleton, Cogan, and Forster 2013)
maps (Becker, Minka, and Deckmyn. 2024)
sf (Pebesma and Bivand 2023)
dartR.base (Gruber et al. 2018)

Restart R in the Session/Restart R drop-down in R Studio and create a log file for the analysis (optional).

library(logr)

Loading required package: common

log_open(file_name = "ZosteropsDistanceFST.log")

[1] "./log/ZosteropsDistanceFST.log"


After making sure they are installed load the libraries for each required package.

library(vcfR)

Data files
This analysis requires the filtered variant call format (VCF) file titled zost.filtered.snps.vcf. Additionally the population of origin and/or taxon assignment will need to be defined for each sample. Taxon and population data for this analysis is in the file titled ZosteropsPOPS_distance.txt. In this file populations are defined in reference to the following combinations of (mostly) allopatric taxa and biogeographic regions. A second taxon assignment file was created assigning individual samples to mostly species designation or more broad allopatric groups within species. That file is titled ZosteropsSPECIES.txt. A detailed description of the assignments in each file is shown below. For discussions of biogeographic breaks in Japan and the Ryukyu Islands see Komaki 2021 (Komaki 2021) and McKay 2012 (McKay 2011).

Population (island and island group) assignments.
Assignment file ZosteropsPOPS_distance.txt

Zosterops japonicus

japonicusKOREA The Korean Peninsula and adjacent islands of the South China Sea and Korean and Tsushima Straits.
japonicusJAPAN The main islands of the Japanese archipelago including Hokkaido, Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu.
japonicusRYUKYUn The northern Ryukyu islands of the Osumi group including Yakushima and Tanegashima. Populations with this designation are those in the broader Ryukyu archipelago but north of the biogeographic break known as Watseâs Line.
japonicusRYUKYUc The central Ryukyu islands including Amami and Okinawa and their adjacent islands.
japonicusRYUKYUs The southern-most Ryukyu islands of the Sakishima group including the Miyako Islands, Yaeyama Islands, and Yonaguni island.
japonicusIZU Populations of the Z. japonicus stejnegeri subspecies from the Izu Islands (including Niijima, Aogashima, Kozushima, and Miyake).
japonicusOGASAWARA Populations of the Z. japonicus alani subspecies in the Ogasawara (including Chichijima, Hahajima, Imotojima, Anejima, and Imotojima islands) and Volcano islands (Iwojima).
japonicusHAWAII Introduced population in the Hawaiian archipelago.

Zosterops meyeni

meyeniLANYU Lanyu island off the east coast of Taiwan.
meyeniBATAN The Batan Islands of the Philippines including Batan and Sabtang islands.

Zosterops montanus

montanusNORTH The Northern Philippine islands of Luzon and Mindoro.
montanusVISAYAS The Visayas region of the central Philippines including the main islands of Negros, Panay, Cebu, Bohol, Leyte, and Samar.
montanusMINDANAO The southern most islands of the Philippines including the island of Mindanao. Included with Z. montanus samples from Mindanao in this analysis is a Z. nigrorum sample (Zni14341). This sample originating from the island of Camiguin South off the northern coast of Mindanao was initially assigned to the Z. nigrorum subspecies catarmanensis but in this study was found to cluster strongly with the central and southern Philippine populations of Z. montanus in both Sanger sequencing and SNP datasets.
montanusPALAWAN Philippine Z. montanus population on the island of Palawan.
montanusINDONESIA Z. montanus populations of the Indonesian archipelago.

Zosterops simplex

simplexASIA All Z. simplex populations on either the island of Taiwan or on mainland continental Asia.
simplexNA Introduced Z. simplex populations in the southern California region of North America.

Additional outgroup taxa

erythropleurus Z. erythropleurus including samples originating in the breeding range in the Russian Far East and wintering individuals in Southeast Asia.
everetti Z. everetti in the Visayas and Southern Philippines.
nigrorum Z. nigrorum in the Visayas and Northern Philippines.
palpebrosus Z. palpebrosus samples from Vietnam.

Species assignments.
Assignment file ZosteropsSPECIES.txt

Zosterops japonicus

japonicus All populations of Z. japonicus in the main islands of Japan, Korean Peninsula, Ryukyu Islands, and Izu islands to Chichijima in the Ogasawara islands and the introduced Z. japonicus population in Hawaii.
japonicusOGASAWARA Populations of the Z. japonicus alani subspecies in the Ogasawara (including Hahajima, Imotojima, Anejima, and Imotojima islands) and Volcano islands (Iwojima) are the most divergent within the Z. japonicus taxon and are for exploratory purposes considered a separate taxon.

Zosterops meyeni

meyeni Populations on Lanyu island off the east coast fo Taiwan and the Batan Islands of the Philippines, including Batan and Sabtang islands.

Zosterops montanus

montanusNORTH The Northern Philippine islands of Luzon and Mindoro.
montanusSOUTH Philippine Z. montanus populations in the Visayas region of the central Philippines including the main islands of Negros, Panay, Cebu, Bohol, Leyte, and Samar and the southern most islands of the Philippines including the island of Mindanao. Included with Z. montanus samples from Mindanao in this analysis is a Z. nigrorum sample (Zni14341), see description in the previous section above.
montanusPALAWAN Philippine Z. montanus population on the island of Palawan.
montanusINDONESIA Z. montanus populations of the Indonesian archipelago.

Zosterops simplex

simplex All Z. simplex populations on either the island of Taiwan or on mainland continental Asia and introduced Z. simplex populations in the southern California region of North America.

Additional outgroup taxa

erythropleurus Z. erythropleurus including samples originating in the breeding range in the Russian Far East and wintering individuals in Southeast Asia.
everetti Z. everetti in the Visayas and Southern Philippines.
nigrorum Z. nigrorum in the Visayas and Northern Philippines.
palpebrosus Z. palpebrosus samples from Vietnam.

Create another set of assignments for mostly species level designations to the individual samples in the SNP dataset from the ZosteropsSPECIES.txt file. Confirm that the IDs in the taxon/population file match the sample IDs in the VCF file.

sample.species.info <- read.table("Data/Taxon files/ZosteropsSPECIES.txt", sep = "\t", header = TRUE) 
sample.species.info <- sample.species.info[sample.species.info$ID %in% colnames(ZosteropsVCF@gt),]

Convert data to Genlight format
Convert the SNP dataset ZosteropsVCF object into a genlight object required for estimating distance and Fst in StAMMP and assign the correct taxa and populations to that object from the ZosteropsPOPS_distance.txt file (sample.info).

ZosteropsGEN <- vcfR2genlight(ZosteropsVCF)
ZosteropsGEN@pop <- as.factor(sample.info$POP)

Convert the SNP dataset ZosteropsVCF object into a genlight object and assign the correct species to that object from the ZosteropsSPECIES.txt assignments (sample.species.info). This genlight object (ZosteropsGENfdiff) will be used for an additional analysis of fixed differences at the species level.

ZosteropsGENfdiff <- vcfR2genlight(ZosteropsVCF)
ZosteropsGENfdiff@pop <- as.factor(sample.species.info$POP)

title: Genetic differentiation and biogeographic breaks
text:
Fixed differences
Conduct a compliance check using the gl.compliance.check function in dartR on the ZosteropsGENfdiff genlight object. Use the gl.fixed.diff function to then count pairwise fixed SNP differences between the assigned species groups. Conduct the pairwise fixed differences analysis under the default parameters including alpha = 0.05 and a threshold value of 0.02 (delta = 0.02). Because these are the default parameters they do not appear as delineated in the command. Include in the fixed differences analysis a statistical test to estimate p-values associated with each pairwise comparison (test = TRUE).

Estimate Fst and Neiâs distance
Generate the Fst and Neiâs distance estimates from the Zosterops genlight object (ZosteropsGEN).

ZosteropsFST <- stamppFst(ZosteropsGEN, nboots = 100, percent = 95, nclusters = 4)
ZosteropsFSTmatrix <- ZosteropsFST$Fsts
ZosteropsFSTmatrix[upper.tri(ZosteropsFSTmatrix)] <- t(ZosteropsFSTmatrix)[upper.tri(ZosteropsFSTmatrix)]
ZosteropsFSTheat <- reshape::melt(ZosteropsFSTmatrix)

Pairwise Fst heatmap
Create a heatmap of the pairwise Fst estimates for each combination of taxa/populations.

ggplot(data = ZosteropsFSTheat, aes(x = X1, y = X2, fill = value))+
  geom_tile()+
  geom_text(data = ZosteropsFSTheat, aes(label = round(value, 2)))+
  theme_minimal()+
  scale_fill_gradient2(low = "white", high = "red", space = "Lab", name = "Fst")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), axis.text.y = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

(`geom_text()`).









Create a heatmap of the pairwise Fst measurements for each combination of taxa/populations but this time reorganize so that populations within the same taxon are kept together and they are ordered based on genetic similarity.

# Define the desired order for the axes
ZosteropsFST_reorder <- c("japonicusJAPAN", "japonicusKOREA", "japonicusRYUKYUn", "japonicusRYUKYUc", "japonicusRYUKYUs", "japonicusIZU", "japonicusOGASAWARA", "japonicusHAWAII", "meyeniLANYU", "meyeniBATAN", "montanusNORTH", "montanusPALAWAN", "montanusVISAYAS", "montanusMINDANAO", "montanusINDONESIA", "simplexASIA", "simplexNA", "erythropleurus", "everetti", "nigrorum", "palpebrosus")
# Convert the factors in the data to match the desired order
ZosteropsFSTheatRO <- ZosteropsFSTheat
ZosteropsFSTheatRO$X1 <- factor(ZosteropsFSTheat$X1, levels = ZosteropsFST_reorder)
ZosteropsFSTheatRO$X2 <- factor(ZosteropsFSTheat$X2, levels = ZosteropsFST_reorder)
# Create the heatmap with ggplot
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data = ZosteropsFSTheatRO, aes(x = X1, y = X2, fill = value)) +
  geom_tile() +  
  geom_text(aes(label = round(value, 2))) +  
  theme_minimal() +  
  scale_fill_gradient2(low = "white", high = "red", space = "Lab", name = "Fst") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), axis.text.y = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

Pairwise Neiâs distance heatmap
Create a heatmap of the Neiâs distance measurements for each combination of taxa/populations.

ZosteropsNeiPOP_mapping <- c("japonicusRYUKYUc", "japonicusRYUKYUs", "japonicusKOREA", "japonicusJAPAN", "japonicusOGASAWARA", "japonicusIZU", "japonicusRYUKYUn", "simplexASIA", "meyeniBATAN", "meyeniLANYU", "montanusVISAYAS", "montanusNORTH", "montanusMINDANAO", "montanusINDONESIA", "montanusPALAWAN", "nigrorum", "erythropleurus", "palpebrosus", "simplexNA", "everetti", "japonicusHAWAII")
# Reassign the X2 column with the mapped text values
ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2 <- ZosteropsNeiPOP_mapping[ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2]
ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2 <- factor(ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2, levels = unique(ZosteropsNeiDheat$X1))
# Create the heatmap matrix
ggplot(data = ZosteropsNeiDheat, aes(x = X1, y = X2, fill = value))+
  geom_tile()+
  geom_text(data = ZosteropsNeiDheat, aes(label = round(value, 4)))+
  theme_minimal()+
  scale_fill_gradient2(low = "white", high = "red", space = "Lab", name = "Nei's distance")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), axis.text.y = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








Create a heatmap of the pairwise Neiâs distances for each combination of taxa/populations but this time reorganize so that populations within the same taxon are kept together and they are ordered based on genetic distance.

ZosteropsNeiPOP_mapping <- c("japonicusRYUKYUc", "japonicusRYUKYUs", "japonicusKOREA", "japonicusJAPAN", "japonicusOGASAWARA", "japonicusIZU", "japonicusRYUKYUn", "simplexASIA", "meyeniBATAN", "meyeniLANYU", "montanusVISAYAS", "montanusNORTH", "montanusMINDANAO", "montanusINDONESIA", "montanusPALAWAN", "nigrorum", "erythropleurus", "palpebrosus", "simplexNA", "everetti", "japonicusHAWAII")
# Reassign the X2 column with the mapped text values
ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2 <- ZosteropsNeiPOP_mapping[ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2]
ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2 <- factor(ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2, levels = unique(ZosteropsNeiDheat$X1))
# Change the order for the heatmap to match the same order for the Fst heatmap
ZosteropsFST_reorder <- c("japonicusJAPAN", "japonicusKOREA", "japonicusRYUKYUn", "japonicusRYUKYUc", "japonicusRYUKYUs", "japonicusIZU", "japonicusOGASAWARA", "japonicusHAWAII", "meyeniLANYU", "meyeniBATAN", "montanusNORTH", "montanusPALAWAN", "montanusVISAYAS", "montanusMINDANAO", "montanusINDONESIA", "simplexASIA", "simplexNA", "erythropleurus", "everetti", "nigrorum", "palpebrosus")
# Convert the factors in the data to match the desired order
ZosteropsNeiDheatRO <- ZosteropsNeiDheat
ZosteropsNeiDheatRO$X1 <- factor(ZosteropsNeiDheat$X1, levels = ZosteropsFST_reorder)
ZosteropsNeiDheatRO$X2 <- factor(ZosteropsNeiDheat$X2, levels = ZosteropsFST_reorder)
# Create the heatmap matrix
ggplot(data = ZosteropsNeiDheatRO, aes(x = X1, y = X2, fill = value))+
  geom_tile()+
  geom_text(data = ZosteropsNeiDheatRO, aes(label = round(value, 4)))+
  theme_minimal()+
  scale_fill_gradient2(low = "white", high = "red", space = "Lab", name = "Nei's distance")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), axis.text.y = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))










Fst map
Create a map showing the major biogeographic breaks for East Asian Zosterops and the pairwise Fst value estimated for the populations on either side of that break. In each case the Fst value was entered into the code manually from the table created in the previous step.

pac <- map_data("world")
ggplot()+
  geom_polygon(data = pac, aes(x=long, y = lat, group = group), fill="lightgrey", col="black", cex=.1)+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(116, 144.3), ylim = c(-5, 44))+
  # Biogeographic break between Minandao and Indonesia FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120, y = 4, xend = 132, yend = 6), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 133, y = 5, label = "0.22"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between Visayas and Minandao FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120, y = 7, xend = 129, yend = 13), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 129.3, y = 11.4, label = "0.12"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between Northern Philippines (Mindoro and Luzon) and Visayas FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120.2, y = 11.4, xend = 128, yend = 14), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 126.9, y = 14.7, label = "0.24"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between Northern Philippines (Mindoro and Luzon) and Palawan FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120.2, y = 9.4, xend = 119.7, yend = 15), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 118, y = 12.5, label = "0.26"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between Bantan Islands and Northen Philippines FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 119, y = 19.7, xend = 125, yend = 20), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 124.5, y = 19, label = "0.15"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between Lanyu and Batan Islands FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 121.2, y = 21.2, xend = 126, yend = 21.2), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 126.9, y = 21, label = "0.08"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between Southern Ryukyu Islands and Lanyu FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 123, y = 29, xend = 123.6, yend = 22), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 125.5, y = 23, label = "0.31"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between Taiwan (simplex) and Lanyu FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 122.5, y = 26, xend = 120.6, yend = 21), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 118.7, y = 23, label = "0.70"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between the central Ryukyu Islands and the Southern Ryukyu Islands FST (Hachisuka's Line)
  geom_segment(aes(x = 124.2, y = 28, xend = 129.2, yend = 22), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 130, y = 23.7, label = "0.04"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between the northern Ryukyu Islands and the central Ryukyu Islands FST (Watase's Line)
  geom_segment(aes(x = 126, y = 29.6, xend = 133, yend = 29.6), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 132.6, y = 28.5, label = "0.06"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between the main islands of Japan and the Northern Ryukyu Islands FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 127, y = 30.8, xend = 133, yend = 31.2), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 134.3, y = 31.2, label = "0.05"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between the Korean Peninsula and surrounding islands and the main islands of Japan FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 126, y = 31, xend = 131, yend = 35), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 125, y = 32.4, label = "0.02"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between the main islands of Japan and the Izu Islands FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 136, y = 32.8, xend = 141, yend = 34.6), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 142, y = 33.6, label = "0.09"), size = 5) +
  # Biogeographic break between the Izu Islands and the Ogasawara and Volcano (Iwo) Islands FST
  geom_segment(aes(x = 139, y = 28, xend = 144, yend = 30), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 144, y = 28.6, label = "0.19"), size = 5) +
  theme_classic()

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
â¹ Please use `linewidth` instead.











Neiâs distance map
Create a map showing the major biogeographic breaks for East Asian Zosterops and Neiâs distance estimates for the populations on either side of that break. In each case the Neiâs distance value was entered into the code manually from the table created in the previous step.

pac <- map_data("world")
ggplot()+
  geom_polygon(data = pac, aes(x=long, y = lat, group = group), fill="lightgrey", col="black", cex=.1)+
  coord_sf(xlim = c(116, 144.3), ylim = c(-5, 44))+
  # Biogeographic break between Minandao and Indonesia Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120, y = 4, xend = 132, yend = 6), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 132, y = 5, label = "0.0146"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between Visayas and Minandao Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120, y = 7, xend = 129, yend = 13), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 127.9, y = 10.9, label = "0.0075"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between Northern Philippines (Mindoro and Luzon) and Visayas Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120.2, y = 11.4, xend = 128, yend = 14), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 127, y = 14.5, label = "0.0137"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between Northern Philippines (Mindoro and Luzon) and Palawan Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 120.2, y = 9.4, xend = 119.7, yend = 15), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 118, y = 13, label = "0.0186"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between Bantan Islands and Northen Philippines Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 119, y = 19.7, xend = 125, yend = 20), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 124.5, y = 19.3, label = "0.0094"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between Lanyu and Batan Islands Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 121.2, y = 21.2, xend = 126, yend = 21.2), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 127, y = 21.3, label = "0.0068"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between Southern Ryukyu Islands and Lanyu Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 122, y = 29, xend = 123.6, yend = 22), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 125.1, y = 23, label = "0.014"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between Taiwan (simplex) and Lanyu Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 122.5, y = 26, xend = 120.6, yend = 21), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 118.7, y = 23, label = "0.0698"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between the central Ryukyu Islands and the Southern Ryukyu Islands Nei's distance (Hachisuka's Line)
  geom_segment(aes(x = 123.2, y = 28, xend = 129.2, yend = 22), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 129.9, y = 23.7, label = "0.0024"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between the northern Ryukyu Islands and the central Ryukyu Islands Nei's distance (Watase's Line)
  geom_segment(aes(x = 126, y = 29.8, xend = 133, yend = 29.6), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 132.6, y = 28.8, label = "0.0037"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between the main islands of Japan and the Northern Ryukyu Islands Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 127, y = 30.8, xend = 134, yend = 31.2), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 135.3, y = 31.5, label = "0.004"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between the Korean Peninsula and surrounding islands and the main islands of Japan Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 126, y = 31, xend = 131, yend = 35), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 125.5, y = 32.4, label = "0.0019"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between the main islands of Japan and the Izu Islands Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 136, y = 32.8, xend = 141, yend = 34.6), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 142, y = 33.9, label = "0.0029"), size = 3) +
  # Biogeographic break between the Izu Islands and the Ogasawara and Volcano (Iwo) Islands Nei's distance
  geom_segment(aes(x = 139, y = 28, xend = 144, yend = 30), linetype = "dashed", size = 1, color = "red") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 144, y = 29, label = "0.0041"), size = 3) +
  theme_classic()

Close log
